title: tourist-information-screens-to-be-taken-down-across-the-borders
story: ELECTRONIC tourist information boards are to be removed from the region next month.Scottish Borders Council bosses have confirmed the interactive screens in Melrose, Tweedbank, Stow and Hawick will be taken down "following a number of issues".The subject was brought up at Wednesdays meeting of Melrose Community Council.The towns board, which is located in Market Square, was erected back in .At the time, community councillors expressed their concerns over the two-metre high gizmo, which took several weeks to connect up to the wi-fi network.And when it was fixed, it was criticised for being in the wrong place and for not showing enough local information.Vice chairwoman of the community council said in : "There seems to be an awful lot on it, apart from Melrose."We want to show visitors what is on offer here, not other towns."Surely this has been constructed in the wrong place. Its been a great deal of trouble at a great deal of expense."This box has been put right in the middle of the most photographic part of town."However Scottish Borders Council have now decided to remove the boards from four Borders communities.A spokesperson told us: ldquoFollowing a number of issues with its visitor information screens the council has taken the decision to terminate its contract with the current provider."As a result the remaining screens in Hawick, Stow, Melrose and Tweedbank will be removed.ldquoThe council is investigating a range of options, including replacement interactive screens and alternate provision.

title: gerda-to-lead-celebrations-of-legendary-filmmaker
story: AN award-winning local actress will be a major player in honouring film-maker Margaret Tait at this years Alchemy Festival.BAFTA-winning actress Gerda Stevenson, who is most notably known for her role as Murrenrsquos mother in Braveheart, is also a director and writer.Gerda, who lives in West Linton, is set to give a keynote talk on Tait and lead the popular Film Walk at this yearrsquos Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival in May.And as part of the celebration of the centenary of the Scottish filmmaker and poet, known as the MT, Stevenson has also been specially commissioned to write a new poem inspired by Taitrsquos work.Gerda won a Scottish BAFTA for her appearance in Margaret Taitrsquos only feature film Blue Black Permanent.It was the first feature film made by a Scottish woman and continues to inspire young female filmmakers to this day.In , Gerda showed off another of her many talents as she was nominated for the MG Alba Scots Traditional Awards in the Scots Singer of the Year category.Within the same year, she was nominated as one the Saltire Societyrsquos Outstanding Women of Scotland.Alchemy Film and Moving Image Festival has been running in Hawick since being established in . The festival has increased in popularity since the beginning and last year they screened  films from  dferent countries.Michael Pattison, Creative Director of Alchemy said: ldquoWe are delighted that Gerda Stevenson will join us for the first MT event in The Borders.ldquoHer special relationship with Margaret Tait, developed as they worked together on Blue Black Permanent, gives her a very particular insight into Taitrsquos le and work.ldquoWe look forward to Gerdarsquos contribution to this yearrsquos festival, especially the poem which she is writing specially for us.The concluding event of the festival, the annual Film Walk, will be led by Gerda and will end in a special film screening at a pop-up cinema.In celebration of MT, this yearrsquos film will be one of her masterpieces Orquil Burn.And Stevensonrsquos specially commissioned poem will be a response to the rsquos film.The full  Alchemy programme, which runs in Hawick from May  to , will be announced on April .

title: oxton-scout-earns-leadership-accolade
story: AN Oxton Scout has been presented with a prestigious honour at the Scottish Parliament.Josh Beaumont, a member of the Lauderdale Scout Group, earned the Explorer Scout Young Leader Belt.The -year-old is only the second Lauderdale Scout to earn the Young Leader belt, mirroring his older sister Abbeyrsquos efforts when she received the award three years ago.His achievement was recognised by Lauderdale MSP Christine Grahame, who presented Josh with his belt during a recent visit to Holyrood with the Lauderdale Scout Group.ldquoI was delighted to be interrogated by Lauderdale Explorer Scout Group at Parliament recently, said Ms Grahame.ldquoNot only to meet these impressive young people but to present to Josh his well-deserved and hard-earned award of his Young Leader belt.ldquoI am sure Joshrsquos achievement will inspire others to follow in his footsteps.The Explorer Scout Young Leader Scheme is an opportunity for Scouts to make a positive impact in their communities and to fulfil the service elements of many of the top awards in Scouting.Josh said: ldquoI am really happy to get my Young Leader belt.ldquoI really enjoy working with the younger sections in the Scout Group.ldquoEarning my belt was not easy but it helped me to learn what makes a good leader.

title: borders-author-brings-the-stage-to-the-page
story: A BORDERS author has released a mammoth work focusing on the history of British theatre.Spanning two volumes, and almost , pages, An Illustrated History of British Theatre and Performance uncovers , years of theatre history, from Roman Britain to the present day.Doctor Robert Leach, who has lived in Selkirk since , has a long association with the world of theatre and performing arts.A former lecturer in English Literature at The University of Edinburgh, Dr Leach has acted in the United States of America and even directed theatre productions in Moscow, and his new books draw on this extensive experience and knowledge.Dr Leach told The Border : ldquoI have spent my le shuttling between active theatre work and academic le, so I suppose the book marries these two careers.ldquoIm retired now and have lots of hours to fill - hence the books!Whereas most writers who have considered the history of theatre have confined themselves to describing events in Londonrsquos west end, Dr Leach is keen to highlight the historical roles played by a erse array of characters from across the country.The Borders, in fact, has its own claim to fame in the storied history of British theatre.ldquoWhen the Scottish Enlightenment challenged a superstitious kirk, pivotal to the argument was a play by a Borderer - The Tragedy of Douglas by John Home, Dr Leach explained.Home, born in Ancrum, is immortalised on the Scott Monument in Edinburgh.The Bordersrsquo role in live theatre and performance is not solely the preserve of the history books, however, and the region is home to numerous thriving amateur dramatic societies and theatrical ventures.Dr Leach believes the theatre still has an important role to play in society.He said: ldquoIn this age of screens, recordings and digital communication of all sorts, the live theatre can reach parts no other art form can.ldquoI am therefore very excited by the new Pub Theatre which makes its debut at the County Hotel in Selkirk.ldquoLong may it flourish!An Illustrated History of British Theatre and Performance, published by Routledge, is available now, priced at pound per volume.

title: search-is-on-to-find-everton-goalkeepers-grave
story: A HERITAGE group associated with Everton Football Club is trying to locate the grave of the goalkeeper who helped them win their first ever Championship.And they believe it could be in the Scottish Borders.Everton Heritage Society has already erected headstones for two other players from north of the Border, Andrew Hannah and Sandy Young, who were buried in unmarked graves.They now want to do the same for David Jardine, who became the Merseyside clubs first keeper to everplay at Goodison Park in .The son of a stonemason from Dumfriesshire ed to Scotland following his football career, living in the Lanarkshire village of Crawford at the start of the twentieth century.His we, Sarah, died after the family moved to a house near Elvanfoot in .They had two sons - John and Robert - and it was from emigration papers from eldest son, Robert, when arriving back from South Africa in the s that it is known David Jardine had retired to a cottage at Causewayend between Biggar and Coulter.Evertons first Goodison Park and Championship-winning goalkeeper died on March ,  at the cottage just outside Biggar.But where he is buried has become a mystery.Tony Onslow from Everton Heritage Society told us: "The obvious place for David to be buried is with his we at Elvanfoot Church but there is no record of him there."We have exhausted every option around South Lanarkshire and also where Davids parents and siblings are buried at Applegarth in Dumfriesshire."There is a chance he was cremated but, again, we can find no record."Everton Heritage Society undertake one or two of these research projects every year with the aim of re-dedicating the grave with a headstone featuring the club crest."David Jardine was born on December , , at Templand in Dumfriesshire.Following school he served his apprenticeship as a tailor but it was while playing as goalkeeper for Mid-Annandale that he attracted attention.In March , at the age of , he accepted a professional contract from English Football Alliance club, Bootle.It was in a game against Merseyside rivals Everton on April ,  that Jardine grabbed the headlines as he helped Bootle pull off a major - shock.The match report in the Football Field periodical stated: "The young Scot between the sticks punched, kicked and caught the ball with great agility."He threw himself down upon the ball in a manner which even the heartbroken Evertonians could not forebear to cheer."Jardine also helped Bootle to lt the Liverpool Senior Cup in his first season.The following November he signed for Everton and made his debut in a - victory over Blackburn Rovers as they went on to win their first ever Football League championship.,params: .pushJardine shared shared goalkeeping duties during   as Everton saw out their final season playing at Anfield.And he was between the posts in the clubs very first league game at the new Goodison Park against Nottingham Forest on September , .Jardine - having played a total of  games for Everton - left Merseyside at the end of the season and signed for Lancashire club Nelson.Although he helped his new team win the Lancashire League, he was toto Scotland and marry Sarah Smith in .Jardine also ed to tailoring - although he did briefly help Wrexham win the Welsh FA Cup in .Mr Onslow added: "We are fairly sure hes not buried anywhere in South Lanarkshire as the council has helped us with our research."We are hoping that there will be descendants of David Jardine still living in the area who can help us."The Everton Heritage Society has already erected two headstones in Scotland.Last year they rededicated the grave of Andrew Hannah at Kilbowie Cemetery in Clydebank.Hannah, who was a Scottish international, is the only footballer to ever captain both Everton and Liverpool.And in  they also erected a stone for Sandy Young, who scored the FA Cup final winning goal against Newcastle in , at Seafield Cemetery in Edinburgh.Civic and religious authorities have records of who is buried where, but researching historic archives can be laborious and often fruitless.Scottish Borders Council has conducted an initial check, after we contacted them, and officers have agreed to carry out a more in-depth investigation of cemeteries around Broughton and up to the South Lanarkshire boundary in the coming weeks.A spokesperson told us: ldquoWe have begun checking our records to seeDavid Jardinersquos unmarked grave is situated in the Borders.Anyone who can help the Everton Heritage Society track down David Jardines grave can contact Mr Onslow at themanfromthehillcountry@hotmail

title: scotrail-in-last-chance-saloon-following-borders-railway-performance
story: NICOLA Sturgeon has warned ScotRail it is in ldquothe last chance saloon following its recent performance.The First Minister said the Dutch-owned Abellio, which has held the -year franchise to run most of the countryrsquos trains since , could be stripped of the dealit fails to improve.Dozens of Borders Railway passengers were left stranded in the capital last Sunday evening after five of the scheduled seven trains to Tweedbank were cancelled.And commuters faced further disruption throughout the week ndash due to signalling problems and staff shortages.At First Ministers Questions on Thursday, Borders MSP Christine Grahame asked Ms Sturgeon whether, in light of ldquotravel chaos on the line, she considered the ScotRail franchise continued to be ldquosustainable.Ms Sturgeon said she was disappointed passengers faced an ldquounacceptable number of cancellations due to staff training, and said ScotRail was working on a remedial plan.Ms Grahame told her the cancellations had continued since Sunday.She said: ldquoThe plan might be delivered. But that doesnrsquot deliver trains. Plans donrsquot drive trains. Isnrsquot it time that the Scottish Government told ScotRail-Abellio itrsquos in the last chance saloon  I certainly think so, and so do my constituents.The question was greeted with applause from Labour MSPs who want Abellio to be stripped of the ScotRail franchise.,params: .pushMs Sturgeon said: ldquoScotRail should treat a remedial plan very much as a last chance saloon. Thatrsquos the very nature of it. ScotRail has been left in doubt that its recent levels of performance, particularly in the Borders and Fe have been completely unacceptable.ldquoWersquove used contractual mechanisms contained with the franchise agreement to require the remedial plan, and ScotRail will publish its performance remedial plan on its website shortly.ldquoThe commitments in the plan have been contracted as a remedial agreement. In the event ScotRail does not achieve improved performance or fails to deliver on its contractual commitments, it does of course run the risk of having the franchise terminated early.Tory MSP Rachael Hamilton, who represents Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire, read a letter from a constituent who said they were ldquogenuinely surprised when the Borders service was on time, and problems caused ldquosignicant stress and anxiety because of lateness at work and fines for collecting their child from nursery.She said hundreds of commuters were ldquoexperiencing transport hell and urged Ms Sturgeon to intervene and personally oversee the remedial plan.However, Ms Sturgeon made it clear she would not intervene.She said: ldquoThe transport secretary will oversee that, because it is part of his responsibilities. However, as First Minister, I, too, will obviously retain a very close interest in the matter.A ScotRail spokesperson said: ldquoEveryone at ScotRail is working flat out to deliver the quality of service that our customers expect and deserve.ldquoOur most recent period of performance is also very encouraging and shows that the investment we are making in Scotlandrsquos Railway is delivering signicant improvements.ldquoWe know there are still areas where we need to improve and we will work closely with Transport Scotland to deliver those improvements.

title: celebrity-support-for-25th-borders-walking-festival
story: TICKETS for the th Scottish Borders Walking Festival, a week-long event held in Selkirk and the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys from September , are set to go on sale later this month ndash and a famous face has signed on to lend support.This yearrsquos event will be kicked off by one of Scotlandrsquos top outdoor writers, and presenter of the BBC Adventure Show, Cameron McNeish.McNeish, who will appear at the festivalrsquos opening night celebrations, was editor of The Great Outdoors magazine for twenty years and still writes regular columns in Scots Magazine, Campervan Magazine, the Herald and for online magazine www.walkhighlands.His most recent best-selling book, Therersquos Always the Hills, with foreword written by Sam Heughan, star of Outlander and a walking enthusiast, won the  lsquoThe Great Outdoorsrsquo Magazine Book of the Year award.Cameron will be giving a presentation on his book with a signing afterwards, while the evening will also see music from local performers Selkirk Silver Band and the Clarsach Duo, Madalaine Cross and Charlotte Tuckwood.This yearrsquos festival will see a total of  guided countryside walks of ied s, taking in routes across the Selkirk, Ettrick and Yarrow Valley areas - from the Southern Upland Way, the Grey Marersquos Tail Waterfall and the Ring orsquo the Loch to the famous Three Brethren and many more.There will be seven daily walks led by local experts and enthusiasts, including a James Hogg Poetry walk in Ettrick, a stroll with a Bowhill Estate Ranger and a tour around the historic Ettrickbridge, led by village residents.The Scottish Borders Walking Festival began in , making it the longest walking festival of its kind in Scotland.The event is organised and run by volunteers for the benefit of the local community and visiting walkers.Keith Robeson, Senior Ranger at Scottish Borders Council, who has been involved since the very beginning, said: ldquoThe Borders really lends itself to walking and the festival moves around dferent towns every year, so gives walkers plenty iety, while being held in September gives us an excellent chance of good weather in Scotland.Sue Briggs, Chair of the Festival Steering Group, added: ldquoWersquore really lucky to have the Selkirk Farmersrsquo Market and the Yarrow Show on during our festival week and the town will also be decorated with weird and wonderful hats as part of the Souter Stormer Yarn Bombers HatFest competition ndash Border Bunnets.ldquoIt is going to be a brilliant atmosphere.Keen hikers will be able to secure tickets for from midnight on March  by visiting www.borderswalking.

title: mp-invites-scotrail-boss-to-galashiels-public-meeting
story: FOLLOWING another week of misery for commuters on the Borders Railway, MP John Lamont has invited the managing director of Scotrail, Alex Hynes, to a public meeting in Galashiels next month.Disruption on the Tweedbank to Edinburgh line has been an ongoing issue, with reports of overcrowding, cancellations and late trains now an almost daily occurrence.After receiving a huge number of complaints from constituents, a public meeting is now being arranged in April to give commuters the opportunity to grill Scotrail over their recent failures.Mr Lamont, who is currently awaiting a response from ScotRail to this invitation, said: ldquoCancellations and overcrowding on the Borders Railway has now become such a problem that people are being put off using the train and are ing to their cars.ldquoAs well as the disruption that is being caused to peoplersquos lives I am also concerned these issues are undermining the case to have the line extended to Hawick and Newcastleton.ldquoI am far from convinced that Scotrail, or the Scottish Government for that matter, understand the level of frustration commuters are feeling in the Borders.ldquoThe line appears to be an afterthought with the Borders route being understaffed and stock being pulled from the Borders to make sure the central belt is getting a good service.ldquoI have no doubt that local people will make their feelings clear next month.Details of the date and venue will be published as soon as they are confirmed.

title: mueller-ends-russia-investigation-what-happens-next
story: US special counsel Robert Mueller has concluded his investigation into Russian interference in the US presidential election and delivered his final report to Attorney General William Barr.Herersquos what to expect next:What happens when the investigation ends Mr Mueller had to submit a report of some kind. It could be bare-bones.Justice Department regulations require only that Mr Mueller give the Attorney General a confidential report that explains the decisions to pursue or decline prosecutions. That could be as simple as a bullet point list or as fulsome as a report running hundreds of pages.What will the Attorney General do William Barr said he envisions two reports, and only one for congressional and public consumption.Mr Barr has said he takes seriously the ldquoshall be confidential part of the regulations governing Mr Muellerrsquos report. He has noted that department protocol says internal memos explaining charging decisions should not be released.During his confirmation hearing, Mr Barr said he would draft, after Mr Mueller turned in his report, a second one for the chairman and ranking members of the House and Senate Judiciary committees. But the regulations provide little guidance for what such a report would say.The Attorney General is required only to say the investigation has concluded and describe or explain any times when he or Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein decided an action Mr Mueller proposed ldquowas so inappropriate or unwarranted that it should not be pursued.In a letter Mr Barr sent on Friday to the four members of the two Judiciary committees, he said there were ldquono such instances. He also said he may be in a position to advise them of Mr Muellerrsquos conclusions ldquoas soon as this weekend.Mr Barr indicated that he expects to use his report to share the results of Mr Muellerrsquos investigation with the public, which the regulations allow him to do. But he has hedged on specics and said his plans could change after speaking with Mr Mueller and Mr Rosenstein.Will Donald Trump be able to see the report It is not yet clear whether Donald Trump will get to see the report It is unclear whether Donald Trump will ask to see the report and under what circumstances he or his attorneys might be able to view it, especially because the document is meant to be confidential for Justice Department leadership.Mr Mueller reports to the Justice Department, not the White House.Mr Barr said at his confirmation hearing that he would not permit White House interference in the investigation. But he has also voiced an expansive view of executive power in which the president s as the countryrsquos chief law enforcement officer and has wide latitude in giving directives to the FBI and Justice Department.Democrats could seize on any disclosure to the president to argue that the report is not confidential and should be immediately provided to them as well.Can Democrats in Congress subpoena Mr Mueller and his report Yes. The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Jerrold Nadler, has said as much.ldquoWe could subpoena the final report. We could subpoena Mueller and ask him in front of the committee what was in your final report. Those are things we could do, Mr Nadler told ABCrsquos This Week in October.But Mr Trump, as the leader of the executive branch, could direct the Justice Department to defy the subpoena, setting the stage for a court fight that would almost certainly go to the Supreme Court..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagaga, title: Mueller ends Russia investigation  u what happens next

title: pm-admits-third-vote-on-her-brexit-deal-may-not-take-place-next-week
story: Theresa May has admitted she may not garner enough support to get her twice-defeated Brexit deal through the Commons next week, amid mounting speculation about the future of her premiership.The Prime Minister wrote to MPs warning thatthere is insufficient support for her Withdrawal Agreement in the coming days that she could seek an extension to Britainrsquos EU membership beyond the European Parliament elections.It came after the DUP ndash whose support will be crucialthe Government is to win ndash indicated they would not back her deal, with the partyrsquos deputy leader Nigel Dodds lamenting the PMrsquos failure to secure any changes to the Northern Ireland backstop while in Brussels.ldquoNothing has changed as far as the Withdrawal Agreement is concerned. We will not accept any deal which poses a long-term risk to the constitutional and economic integrity of the United Kingdom, he said.Mrs May sought to soften her approach in her letter to parliamentarians, offering to hold talks with MPs and thanking those who have backed her plan previously.And she laid out the choices available to the Commons after she agreed a delay to Brexit with EU leaders in Brussels on Thursday night.The PM said the UK could revoke Article  leave without a deal ask for an extension beyond April her deal is rejected or not voted on or leave on May it is finally approved.Mrs May wrote: ldquoIf it appears that there is not sufficient support to bring the deal back next week, or the House rejects it again, we can ask for another extension before  April ndash but that will involve holding European Parliament elections.ldquoIf it appears that there is sufficient support and the Speaker permits it, we can bring the deal back next week andit is approved we can leave on  May.It came as ministers moved to try to head off an attempt by MPs to seize control of Commons business in a bid to secure a ldquosofter Brexit.A cross-party group of pro-EU MPs claimed they had the numbers to force a series of ldquoindicative votes on alternatives to Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal.But Business Secretary Greg Clark said the Government was prepared to enable Parliament to express a view on the ious optionsMrs Mayrsquos deal is rejected by the Commons for a third time next week.Defeat for the Government on Monday on the amendment ndash tabled by former ministers Sir Oliver Letwin and Dominic Grieve and Labour MP Hilary Benn ndash would be a further humiliation for Mrs May.A cross-party group of pro-EU MPs claim they have the numbers to force a series of ldquoindicative votes in the Commons If the amendment is passed, it would pave the way for a series of ldquoindicative votes in the House on Wednesday, effectively taking control of the Brexit process out of the hands of the Government.Elsewhere it emerged that Tory former foreign secretary Boris Johnson met Mrs May for talks twice this week, including on Friday.Mr Johnson is said to have asked the PM how she intended to change her approach, and she reportedly set out plans to restructure the Department for Exiting the European Union.Hundreds of thousands of supporters of a second referendum will march through central London on Saturday, where Labourrsquos deputy leader Tom Watson is expected to say he will vote for the PMrsquos dealit is put to the people.Meanwhile Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has been reluctant to throw his full weight behind a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, will be campaigning in the North West of England.As Mrs May battles to stay in Number , Prisons Minister Rory Stewart said replacing her would not help the situation.ldquoI would rather she stayed because I donrsquot believe that changing Theresa May for someone  is going to resolve this problem, he told BBC Tworsquos Newsnight.ldquoThe problems are deep in the wounds of the vote, Parliament, the European Union ndash itrsquos not about a single inidual..push,i[r].l*new title: dale see signs of recovery in tough conditions
story: Glasgow University B Greater Glasgow Football League Div After a series of heavy defeats, partly due to injuries, Carradale performed very well against a side, second in the league and looking for promotion.Carradale chose to play with the strong wind in the first half and pressed forward with the advantage it gave.Early on DJ slipped a ball through to Nanek who beat the keeper only to see the ball slam into the post and the danger was cleared.#Dale played a high line attacking position, but with all credit to Glasgow University they passed the ball round and were always a danger on the break.#Dale had three free kicks from corners of the box but none disturbed the opposition keeper.Midway through the first half a lull in the weather gave Glasgow a chance and slick passing manoeuvres, with eight players involved in each finished with Deans scoring from  yards out in the th minute.The Kintyre side was very unfortunate not to equalise a minute later, when Elliot Gemmill, on the right wing, cut inside the full back and his first time effort, from the corner of the box, came crashing off the crossbar.The McFadyens Transport sponsored #Dale finally equalised in the  minute, again the Glasgow side were playing from the back but DJ took full advantage.He scored with a thumping shot into the back of the net having dispossessed the keeper.On the stroke of half-time Matthew Lang playing with Nanek had a chance to put #Dale ahead but the keeper saved the shot.Carradale knew they would be under pressure from the well drilled University side, when playing against the wind and tried to play a high level going into the second half.But the away side caught them offside. Craig Galbraith worked well playing with, eventual man of the match, Calum Johnson for the first time.In the th minute there was a skirmish in the box after a corner, Johnson cleared the ball but it ricocheted off the incoming player into the net.The Glasgow students had more possession with the wind advantage. With  minutes left, a tremendous fingertip save, by Neil McMillan, pushed the ball over the bar.With four minutes left the away side put the game beyond #Dale#s reach when Matthew Lamont tried to clear a corner shot but unforunately scored an own goal.In high winds and driving rain the game fizzled out.Both sides had played well in the conditions and kept the ball on the deck in addition, referee, Archie Mitchell said it was an easy game to ref with no bad tackles.The match ball was sponsored by Wee Toon Sports and a Carradale spokesperson thanked Food for Thought for the post match hospitality.Tomorrow Carradale travels to Helensburgh for an early kick off at noon.

title: machrihanish bay is britains second best beach
story: The bay, which is the beginning of the longest continuous stretch of sand in Argyll, extending all the way to Westport, was second only to Sandown Bay on the Isle of White in the BBC Countryfile Magazine Awards .After a long and detailed judging process to determine the shortlist for each category, the magazine#s readers and website visitors were given a month to vote for their favourites, with winners announced last week.The magazine#s editor, Fergus Collins, said: #Congratulations to each of the winners – and all the people and places who were shortlisted.#The aim of our awards is to celebrate the best of the British countryside and shine a light on lesser known places, projects and people who are doing great work.#Westport beach looking towards Machrihanish Bay. _cwestport

title: down memory lane march 15 2019
story: Peter Docherty, born and brought up in the Wee Toon, lives in a first floor flat, in Tangy Place tenement, at the end of the High Street, with a #marvellous# view of all the comings and goings on Campbeltown Loch.Back in , aged , he was an apprentice painter and decorator for a town firm, which he thinks might have been Galbraith and Cochrane.Mr Docherty#s son, also Peter, , talked to the Courier on Monday and said: #Dad told me that the young apprentices were always given the awkward, high up places to paint.#Back then this wall must have been under a ceiling as now the graffiti chipped into the plaster is at waist height.#Painters always used to leave their mark on a building, many will be painted over in people#s houses.#They often wonderedtheir #marks# would be uncovered in the future.#On this wall they could see the names of people who had painted it in the past.#When he saw Down Memory Lane last week dad said he was the only P Docherty in the town at the time.#Peter junior, who visits two to three times a year, said: #I was born in Craigard. When I was aged two dad left the town for a career as a policeman in Bedfordshire.#Following  years police service, PC Docherty, retired having spent his final time at Kempston, the Bedfordshire police headquarters.Peter jun added: #Dad moved back to Campbeltown in .#My sister Karen was also born in Campbeltown in  and today she lives three doors away from me in the same Milton Keynes street.#Karen is a keen photographer and takes about  pictures a day and has documented the family.#My brother George was born in , in England and he lives in Lincolnshire.#When we used to come to Kintyre, for holidays as children, we joked that we would need to bring George#s passport to allow him across the border.#If anyone recalls who M.M.S. or JW is from , as carved in this Craigowan tree and featured last week, the Courier would like to print the story. _cmemorylane_Tree_graffittiP Docherty eteched into a wall for posterity. _cmemorylane_grafitti_Courier

title: letter budget winners and losers
story: Another year and another budget for the council and as always there are winners and losers.I have to congratulate all the officers of the council, particularly Kirsty Flanagan, head of strategic finance and her team, for being so helpful during this process.I also thank the leader of the council for the manner in which the papers were presented this year which made alternative motions possible.However what did this year yield The main dferences in the budget came down to the administration of the council proposing £, more for winter gritting, outwith the A which is covered by the contract with BEAR.This was against cuts in the road safety unit, an award-winning safety programme for young children, a cut in youth and adult learning, a cut in environmental warden services, which means a focus on more fines but less time for fly tipping and dog fouling and a cut to music tuition in schools.There were amendments lodged by Councillor Donald Kelly and myself, the SNP group and councillors George Freeman and Jean Moffat.While gritting our roads is important Councillor Kelly and I, along with other council opposition groups, thought the other considerations were important to our communities which strangely enough is also supported by our corporate plan.Alas the gritting won the day.Full motions and votes can be found on the council website.However it was more disappointing that Councillor Kelly and I included in our motion a scheme to change funding due for Helensburgh and Dunoon.Just more than £ million would be moved to the regeneration project of Tarbert Lochgilphead Ardrishaig.This was defeated by the rest of the council which was particularly galling.Money for Helensburgh had been questioned by its community council which felt that too much had already been spent.The money for Dunoon was because of poor procurement processes and a general #I want syndrome# all to the detriment of this its area.It is local democracy at work which should be communicated to our communities.Councillor Douglas Philand,

title: letter dog mess despoils quarry green
story: Last Thursday, on Facebook#s page The Wee Toon Community Noticeboard, William Crossan wrote: #To dog owners who walk their dog on the Quarry Green, along Kilkerran Road: #Please make sure you pick up its plop and not just leave it lying there.##This area has become appalling with the amount of doggy do just left behind by feckless owners.#It#s the worst I#ve ever seen it in nearly  years walking my own dogs there.#For goodness sake show some common decency and pick up after your dog.#Maryflora Macphail agreed: #It’s a disgrace as a dog walker myself I’m disgusted with the mess of such a lovely spot.#Bobbiemarie Stalker added: #Also along Long-Row it’s everywhere and it’s disgusting,you can#t pick up after your dog you shouldn’t have one.#Stuart Lawson commented: #I think the council need to put covert CCTV around the worst places in town to catch the culprits.#Donna McCrimmon said: #It#s the everywhere near Dalintober School I can#t believe people leave it.#Lisa Nicolson said: #There is not one single environmental enforcement officer, in other words dog warden in the whole of Argyll and Bute either.#No deterrent for these ignorant folk.#Karen Mcgougan added: #Its actually getting really bad,I can understand that not always possible to get every bit but the sxxt I see on way down to Tesco could easily be picked up.#I went over one day and picked it up as I was title: machrihanish golf club members approve plans
story: Machrihanish Golf Club#s clubhouse was completely burned down in a devastating fire, on December  last year, which also destroyed the family home of its steward.A club extraordinary general meeting was held on March  in the Argyll Arms Hotel, attended by  members of whom  had voting rights.The club committee put forward proposals by Glasgow architects G and  members voted in favour of the principle design, five against and there were three abstentions.At the meeting a sub-committee, which will administer the club#s side of the project and see it through the two-year build period, was formally announced.The sub-committee is the current captain Calum MacMillan, vice-captain Willie Ross, Keith Crawford and Willie Livingstone.G will project manage and employ the necessary professionals to see the project through.Speaking exclusively to the Courier Calum MacMillan said: #We hope to be open by or before December   as the club has a two business interruption insurance policy.#The architects are already working day, night and at weekends.#In the new clubhouse everyone will be in together. It is the perfect opportunity to make everyone feel part of the club, with ladies, gents and juniors in one clubhouse.#It will have a lt and accessible toilets and showers. In future for every  car parking spaces we will require one accessible space.#We hope to have access at the front of the building.#The current design is a principle one but it is open to change, the club#s constitution says thatthere are substantial changes to the clubhouse or course there must be an EGM.#A Portacabin village has been erected behind the ladies# clubhouse paid for through the club#s insurance and it has  lockers, changing facilities, an office and a meeting room.Mr MacMillan added: #We would like to give particular thanks to McFadyens Contractors for their professional work and their quotation at a very competitive price.#We are constructing a temporary car park across the back wall which McFadyens will start in the near future.#We also want to thanks the Argyll Arms for hosting the EGM and G Architects for their excellent presentation.#Next Saturday the Machrihanish  season kicks off with the Peace Cup, a medal play for gents, ladies and juniors.The club#s annual general meeting is on Friday April  at the Argyll Arms Hotel, Campbeltown.McFadyens Contractors have demolished the Machrihanish Golf clubhouse. In the background, right, are the Portacabin changing facilities and in front of the ladies# clubhouse. _cmachgolfAn artist#s impression of the new clubhouse. NO_cclubhouse

title: mok fest 2019 set to rock the wee toon
story: The  Mull of Kintyre Music Festivalbrings some of the best bands and performers from across Scotland to perform at the five-day event which runs from August  to .The Saturday night concert in title: letter live argyll price increase
story: I have just received three envelopes from ‘ Live Argyll’ in Oban.On opening the first I found it to be leaflet headed #We’ve taken the £££’s OFF with our new membership prices#.I am well aware that you know what is written on your leaflet, but for those people who haven’t read it I enclose the leaflets next paragraph:#Following a detailed analysis of our pricing structure, Live Argyll are introducing a new low cost membership scheme.#In short, we’ve decided to shed some pounds. From st April your direct debit will be amended in line with the new pricing structure. Same fantastic facilities, at a much reduced cost.#What good news I thought as I rushed to open letter number two.This letter told me that from st April my we’s swimming concession membership would be increasing from £. to £. per month.This is a  per cent increase in charges, I then went back to letter one and read it again and it definitely said ‘at a much reduced cost’.I then slowly opened letter three wondering what it would be about.Possibly news that the car park was now ready for use after months of work, but alas no. It just gave details of when you would collect the new direct debit.I feel a  per cent increase in pensioners# swimming concessions is really excessive in the present climate.I also think that the department which writes your leaflets and your finance management should get together and try to explain to the public how they interpret the sentence #Same fantastic facilities, at a much reduced cost #.Next time the three letters should be in one envelope – it’s cheaper.Geoffrey BellKilkerran Cottage,Kilkerran Road,Campbeltown.

title: thought for the week march 15 2019
story: It made me wonder why someone would choose the period of Lent for that purpose. Why not give up something at any timeLent is irrelevant For centuries, Christians have chosen to deny themselves things they enjoy on their journey during Lent. This usually takes the form of chocolate or alcohol or whatever luxury would be sorely missed.It is a time of abstinence and is meant to focus attention on the spiritual journey as we walk the Easter road once again.However it is becoming more popular now to take something on, rather than give something up.People engage in ious activities from committing to write a letter to a prisoner of conscience every day via Amnesty International, to serving in a soup kitchen.There is much we can do in this world. A world in danger from climate change, war, abuse of power, and general disregard for the fragility of the planet.Online petitions flood into our mailboxes every day asking us to sign them for a multitude of worthy causes, and it is dficult to keep up with it all.However maybe we could make a decision this Lent to focus on one of these issues, and make a personal resolution to do something to help.As we think of Jesus taking on the power of the Roman army and the might of the establishment, we know that even one person can make a dference.Yes, that one person was Jesus. But didn#t he promise to send his spirit to be with us – to make a dference

title: letter arran ferry service plea
story: As chair of the Lochranza and Catacol Community Association on the Isle of Arran I have written to the chief executive of Transport Scotland.The association has asked him to revisit the recently rejected proposal for a Lochranza to Claonaig winter ferry service.The association firmly believes that the potential strategic benefits of piloting such a service would, given time, prove highly signicant.Businesses in Arran and Argyll, of all kinds, would benefit greatly, and the through Arran route would open up lines of communication, and closer ties in terms of tourism, transport and infrastructure.The perceived benefits would be felt on Arran, but more so, on the mainland, particularly in Kintyre and Argyll, which have much to gain from an enhanced all year service.It is worth mentioning that this service seems, in terms of weather and technical reliability, to have signicantly better resilience than the Brodick to Ardrossan service.Offering a year-round alternative means of getting on and off the island, particularly in unforeseen circumstances, is in the views of many, not only desirable, but essential.I have copied this letter to other interested parties including the first minister Nicola Sturgeon.Ken Thorburn,

story: So it was on Monday when CalMac#s diesel-electric MV Catriona, one of the newest vessels in the fleet, was brought into service on the Cloanaig to Lochranza run.Its job, almost unbeliveably,  was to alleviate pressure at Ardrossan,  miles away, where a crash caused a smaller vessel to be operating.The super smooth, almost silent ferry, ran a continuous shuttle and judging by the midday sailing immediately became popular.Not everyone had driven round, for some Kintyre folk it offered an easy day out on Arran.A number of Islay and whisky tourists were able to include Lochranza Distillery on their itineraries.This begs the question: Why not upgrade the single-track B between Claonaig and Kennacraig to improve it for winter A year round Cloanaig to Lochranza service may reinvigorate trade between one of Arran#s iconic villages, Skipness, Tarbert, Kintyre and Islay.Springbank and Glen Scotia distilleries have found whisky tourists are not seasonal. title: thought for the week march 22 2019
story: Usually I purchase an inexpensive skylight filter to protect the lens from scratches or damage.The theory being that it is far easier and less expensive to replace an inexpensive filter than a very expensive lens.However I was intrigued when I began to research the best filter for my requirements.I was being offered a completely clear glass filter for way more than I would normally pay for a simple skylight filter.At first I thought: #Why on earth would I pay such a lot of money for something which is just a piece of clear glass #However when I read the reasons given to purchase this clear piece of glass, I was convinced.The logic was this – why pay a lot of money for a top-class lens, and then put a cheap filter on it Why not let the lens do the job you have paid it to do, and simply protect it with the finest clearest glass you can get.I thought of the words of St Paul who said: #For now we see through a glass, darkly but then face to face: now I know in part but then shall I know even as also I am known.#Somehow my clear glass filter gives me the best image reproduction I can have.In our earthly le, we see Jesus as best we can, perhaps through a skylight filter, but just think that in time there will be nothing to dull our vision and we will see him in all his glory # crystal clear and face to face.

title: top-jockey-peter-scudamore-helps-launch-new-replay-cards-at-musselburgh-racecourse
story: On-hand to support the initiative last week was eight-time champion jockey Peter Scudamore MBE and local MP Martin Whitfield.Mr Scudamore joined local Sporting Memories groups, volunteers and other local racing representatives to talk about his time as a jockey and trainer and share his memories and stories. He also took part in a question-and-answer session involving group members.The launch at Musselburgh, Scotlandrsquos second biggest racecourse, was held by Sporting Memories in partnership with Racing Welfare Scotland and Racing Together. It ran simultaneously with another launch event at Palace House, The National Heritage Centre for Horseracing  Sporting Art, at Newmarket.The sporting aid memory cards feature the great and the good of horseracing throughout history and were compiled with the assistance of Racing Welfarersquos Malton-based welfare team to support older people living with dementia, depression and loneliness. The cards have an image of a sporting legend on the front and some information about their achievements on the back.Sporting Memories produces a number of resources and materials to inspire and promote reminiscence, which are then available for third-party organisations to buy to utilise at their own events.Chris Wilkins, co-founder and director of Sporting Memories Network, said: ldquoThe Sporting Memories Foundation in England and Scotland uses sports reminiscence to engage isolated older people living with conditions such as dementia, loneliness and depression.ldquoOur club members, who meet on a weekly basis in locations across the UK, are brought together through a shared love of sport, and enjoy using our replay reminiscence cards that help trigger memories and conversation.ldquoWe have already produced a range of replay cards which reflect a wide selection of sports, and we are now delighted to launch our latest set on racing, which will help to trigger memories of watching or participating in horseracing.ldquoThemes for the cards were suggested by members of our Racing Welfare Sporting Memories Club at Malton and reflect some of the great jockeys, horses and courses that together represent some of the best and most enduring memories of racing.ldquoImages can be very powerful in helping prompt memories and stories which, particularly for people living with dementia, can otherwise remain locked away and untold. Our aim is to unlock those stories and together celebrate some wonderful racing memories.ldquoWe couldnrsquot deliver our work without the support of volunteers and we are always looking for other sports fans who might be interested in supporting the fun and fulfilling activities that take place in our weekly clubs. Information about our clubs and volunteering opportunities can be found at our website thesmfMP Mr Whitfield said: ldquoI was delighted to attend the launch of the Sporting Memories Foundationrsquos new racing replay cards in Musselburgh.ldquoThese cards are another great resource from Sporting Memories, which has an extensive range of sporting memory aids. Listening to Peterrsquos stories and the memories they evoked in others made it clear what a valuable tool they can be for those living with dementia.ldquoI commend Sporting Memories and Racing Welfare on this welcome initiative and their other activity supporting older and vulnerable people.

title: east-lothian-council-services-for-hire
story: The council is looking at ways to bring in extra revenue in the next three years by capitalising on its services and the influx of new housing in the county.Burial plots in two new cemeteries will be made available for advance sales as the council re-opens the pre-sale of lairs in Dunbar and Prestonpans, where capacity issues have seen the practice suspended in recent years. New housing developments in the towns have seen plans put forward for new graveyards to cope with the increasing populations.In Prestonpans, a proposed cemetery is included with plans to build  houses at Dolphingstone Farm while in Dunbar plans for a new graveyard at Newtonlees have been approved by the council.A council spokesperson said advance sales were withdrawn in the towns to ensure lairs were available for immediate need as they ran out of space.However, he confirmed: ldquoIt is expected that, as the new provision opens in Prestonpans and Dunbar, we will be in a position to process requests.As further new sites are developed, it is anticipated this option will become more widely available.It is anticipated the move will bring an additional pound, in revenue for the local authority in the next financial year as people queue up to book plots in their home towns.The move is one of a number of ventures which have been given the go-ahead in the councilrsquos budget plans for the next three years to maximise income.It also includes plans to bid to take over factoring contracts for landscaping in new housing developments and offer to install play equipment and areas in the same estates.The local authority is looking to capitalise on the influx of housing into the county, which is seeing up to , new homes being built across its communities.It hopes that it can compete with private factoring firms to take on responsibility for public areas within new housing estates, which developers traditionally hand on to independent factors.And it has budgeted a potential income of up to pound, by providing the commercial service over the next three years, as well as a further pound, by offering to install play areas in the new developments.The council said it was seeking to develop ldquocommercial opportunities across all services.The spokesman said: ldquoGiven the countyrsquos growth agenda, these are areas that we intend to explore.

title: man-who-slept-in-van-after-drinking-avoids-driving-ban
story: Mario Delacruz, , was caught sleeping in his van in an Edinburgh car park after he had been out drinking with friends in the city last year.Delacruz was spotted by police officers sleeping in the passenger seat of his van but they also saw his keys were lying nearby on the driverrsquos seat.The officers woke the Spanish national up and, after noticing he had been drinking alcohol, decided to breathalyse him.The tests showed that Delacruz, of The Promenade, was more than four times the drink-drive limit.Delacruz appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court, where he pleaded guilty to being in charge of the vehicle at the time on October  last year.Solicitor Peter OrsquoNeill said that his client had been out with friends in the Leith area of the city and had decided to ldquosleep it off before going home the following day.Mr OrsquoNeill said that Delacruz had been in the UK for about five years and had moved to Scotland last July.He currently works as a cleaner and has sold the van he was found sleeping in.The lawyer added: ldquoHe is sorry and knows it should not have happened.Sherf John Cook fined Delacruz pound and told him that he would have  penalty points placed on his licence.Delacruz pleaded guilty to being in charge of a motor vehicle with mcg of alcohol in ml of breath at Nichollfield, Edinburgh, on October  last year. The legal limit is  mcg.

title: port-seton-man-offers-to-clean-gardens-of-dog-waste
story: Super Pet Scooper was founded in January by Port Seton man Greg Mahony, of Laburnum Avenue, who will be servicing the East Lothian area for its doggy clear-up needs.ldquoI was looking for a business opportunity in the area, Greg said.ldquoCleaning gardens of dog waste is big in the USA and Canada, and even England, but not around here, so I saw a gap in the marketOriginally from Manchester, Greg and his family fell in love with all East Lothian had to offer, especially when walking his own rescue dog, Rocco. It was then he noticed that dog fouling in the area was becoming an issue.ldquoOur community wants to live in a nice environment, he said.ldquoWe promote responsible ownership, enforce fines and put up signs, but sometimes itrsquos just not enough.ldquoMany dog owners, like myself, always take doggie bags to clean up the waste, but sadly, many owners do not.This was when Greg came up with the idea for Super Pet Scooper.ldquoI never thought Irsquod start a business, but I wanted to do something that would help people and I love animals, especially dogs, so it made sense, he said.ldquoI donrsquot mind cleaning up after dogs, it doesnrsquot bother me! It also gets me out and about on a weekend, as well as a little more income.Greg works during the week for the NHS but has high hopes that he can build his company to a full-time role.ldquoAt the moment, Irsquom only part-time but Irsquom hoping to expand, he said.ldquoI got in touch with East Lothian Council for advice and they were fantastic, helped me get my waste carrier licence and advice on business insurance and things.Despite only being in his first month of business, the -year-old has a few clients and has been getting good reviews across Facebook.ldquoIrsquove had a positive reaction to the company, he said. ldquoI know a lot of people think thatyou have a dog you should be able to clean up after them yourself, but a lot of people canrsquot. They can fall ill or just become unable to move around like they used to, so thatrsquos where I can help.

title: pictures-a-look-around-the-new-wallyford-primary-school
story: The move to the new pound.million Wallyford Primary School took place on February .Mhairi Stratton, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquove been really impressed at how quickly the children have settled into their new school. Theyrsquore enjoying the outdoor space and the freedom it gives them.ldquoThe more open classroom layouts are also great and very flexible for learning and play.As pupils settle into the new school, which boasts  classrooms and a further four nursery playrooms, East Lothian Council is in the process of securing land for a second high school for the Musselburgh area.The approval of the new high school, which will be built on land near Dolphingstone and take in students from the Pinkie area of Musselburgh, as well as Wallyford, was given at a meeting of East Lothian Council in December .The new high school was expected to begin taking in pupils from August , or as soon as possible after that date.But the council then wrote to all concerned to tell them that the expected opening of the school had now been put back to August .The decision to build a new secondary school near Wallyford followed a public consultation after it became clear that Musselburgh Grammar School would not be able to cope with the expected influx of new residents as a result of extensive housebuilding in Musselburgh and Wallyford.Three options were put forward: extend the current Grammar building create an upper and lower school on two campuses or build a new secondary school to complement Musselburgh Grammar.The council said a clear majority was in favour of building a new school but some labelled the consultation ldquoflawed.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe are in the process of securing the land for a new secondary provision for the Musselburgh area. Our capital budget for the five-year period  -  has allocated pound.m towards the project and developer contributions will be secured towards this investment.No decision has been taken on the future of the former Wallyford Primary School building at Salters Road, which was too small to accommodate the rising population.Land was secured on the east side of the town on the St Clementrsquos Wells development to create a new primary school campus to offer room for modern educational facilities for a growing school population, surrounded by plenty of outdoor space.The council spokesperson said: ldquoNow that the new Wallyford Primary School is open and ing, we are in the final stages of moving equipment from the old school.ldquoNo decision has been taken on the future of the former school site but the council will be considering options.

title: search-for-headteacher-for-new-merged-prestonpans-primary-school
story: That comes after it was confirmed that the current headteachers of both schools would not be putting their names forward for the role.East Lothian Council approved a merger of the two schools last December.The local authority has now confirmed that neither the current headteacher of Prestonpans Primary, Jonathan Revell, nor of Prestonpans Infant School, Sheila Laing, will be applying for the role.Sheila Laing became headteacher at Prestonpans Infant School in September , moving from Campie Primary School in Musselburgh, while Mr Revell was appointed headteacher at Prestonpans Primary in September .A video has been posted on Prestonpans Primary Schoolrsquos Twitter feed and its parent council Facebook page in which pupils and teachers appeal for candidates to apply.In the video, Fiona Robertson, head of education at the council, states the need for someone who can ldquobelieve, achieve, strive for excellence and care for all.The video also sees the children demonstrate their cooking and sign language skills, with one child adding: ldquoThe best teachers you could ever wish for are in this school.ldquoThere are lots of fun and dferent events happening throughout the year.Councillor Shamin Akhtar, cabinet member for education, told the Courier: ldquoThis is a great opportunity for someone who is passionate about supporting an amazing school and its local community.ldquoThere is already lots of great work happening in Prestonpans, especially in supporting and engaging with parents and carers, which has received national recognition. We need someone who will continue to build upon this work and support our children and young people to achieve their fullest potential.The appeal for the new headteacher coincides with a consultation that has been opened by the council to give a name to the new school.The name of the school, as suggested by the council, should be based on either a notable person from the area, the location of the school or include the vision of the school.The consultation closes on March , and any suggestions can be either emailed to educationconsultations@eastlothian.gov.uk or posted to John Muir House, Haddington.The new school will follow a single curriculum. There are no plans to move buildings, with the new school running across the two former education establishments.

title: belhaven-bays-baywatch-to-patrol-the-beach-this-summer
story: A grant of pound, has been given to Dunbar Surf Le Saving Clubto run the project, which will see training given to volunteers, as well as raising awareness of the risks associated with the coast.The money, from the Big Lottery Fund, will ensure the Dunbar organisation is the first of its kind in Scotland to run a volunteer Beach Surf Lesaving Patrol.Sally Harris, head coach of DSLSC, told the Courier: ldquoWe are absolutely delighted to receive this funding from the National Lottery.ldquoWe will now be able to put together Scotlandrsquos first community-led voluntary surf lesaving beach patrol team in Dunbar.ldquoThe funding will also allow us to continue our preventative education programme, helping to reduce the national coastal drowning statistics.The aims of the Belhaven Bay Community Le Saving Beach Patrol are to provide a lesaving service for the community and visitors, to prevent accidental drowning and injury among beach users.Training will also be given to young people and adults in the community to deliver the services while also raising awareness of the risks associated with using the beach and sea.In , more than  people drowned in the UK.Belhaven Bay, within John Muir Country Park, is a favourite spot for surfers, open-water swimmers and water sports enthusiasts from across the country and beyond.The Beach Patrol will initially operate during the busy summer weekends.Dunbar and East Linton ward member Councillor Norman Hampshire welcomed the scheme.He said: ldquoAs the local ward councillor, I am delighted that Belhaven lsquoBaywatchrsquo with Scotlandrsquos first volunteer Beach Patrol Service are going to start this year.ldquoI would like to congratulate them on their successful application to the Big Lottery.ldquoThis will provide some good training opportunities for young people and adults in the area.George Robertson, chairman of Dunbar and East Linton Area Partnership, wished the club the best of luck.He said: ldquoIt is a worthwhile objective andit makes the beach safer one must applaud it.

title: world-champion-sprinter-maria-lyle-thanks-her-mum-for-rekindling-her-love-of-athletics
story: Maria Lyle ed from the Fazza International Championships in Dubai recently with two gold medals.However, it was just last year that she broke down in tears during her ldquodarkest moment before a major competition.The teenager has lived with diplegic cerebral palsy in her legs almost all her le.The -year-old told the Courier that her mum Susan had been with her throughout her journey, which has seen her represent Great Britain in the Paralympics and Scotland in the Commonwealth Games.Her mum is a PE teacher at Dunbar Primary School and taught Maria.Keen for Maria to be involved as much as her peers, but with little experience of teaching pupils with a disability, Susan looked for ways to deliver lessons which allowed Maria to flourish.Maria said: ldquoWhen I was younger, I struggled quite a lot. Things didnrsquot come quite as naturally for me as they did for my peers and often I ended up feeling a bit rubbish about myself.ldquoThings drastically changed, however, after one PE lesson. We had to complete the multi-stage fitness test .ldquoAs someone who fell over constantly and ended up with cut knees  per cent of the time, you could say I wasnrsquot that keen to join the lesson.ldquoTo everyonersquos surprise, I was the last one left in the test. That was the first time Irsquod ever felt such a sense of achievement. From that moment, running would become a big part of my le.Those short runs started to build Mariarsquos strength.She became European champion in  and within the next four years Paralympic, World and Commonwealth medals followed.But despite all her success, Maria couldnrsquot find the same love for her sport as she had during those early runs with her mum. The teenager became overwhelmed with worry about competing and her concerns impacted her le away from the track.After suffering in silence for years, Maria finally opened up to her mum, who convinced her to seek professional help. She was later diagnosed with having anxiety.Maria, who works at the Scottish Parliament as a committee assistant, said: ldquoMy mum would give up lots of her time, she would lead my sessions and drive me all over the country so I could compete. She would even take time off work to watch me in competitions. Because of this I would get worriedI didnrsquot run well.ldquoIrsquod feel guilty about wasting her time. Disappointing my mum wasnrsquot the only thing I was anxious about. I was worried about my competitors and factors I couldnrsquot control.ldquoBefore the  European Championships, I revealed something to my mum that I had never spoken about before. I broke down and cried for hours expressing how rubbish I felt about myself in both my running and personal le.ldquoRunning had completely taken over and there was nothing positive.ldquoIn my darkest moment, my mum was there for me.ldquoShe was the one who listened for hours. She was the one who hugged me. From that day, my mum and my immediate family have supported me. They have made me realise that there is more to le than running.Susan said that no medal ceremony could compare to seeing her daughter enjoying running again. She said: ldquoMy proudest moment is not Maria winning medals on the world stage, it is probably Maria competing in Glasgow last weekend at the  National Indoor Championships.ldquoFor the first time in years, I saw Maria stand on the start line feeling relaxed and running through the finish line with a smile on her face.ldquoAlong with the support from us as a family and her coach, Jamie Bowie, Maria has turned herself around and is back on track in all areas of her le.

title: brexit-live-prime-minister-loses-commons-vote-on-brexit-proposals
story: Herersquos how events unfolded and the reaction that followed:.pmTory former Brexit minister Steve Baker said he had tabled a ldquoMalthouse Compromise amendment to Wednesdayrsquos motion with Tory colleagues which would seek extension of Article  until May .The motion states: ldquoThat this House notes the steps taken by the Government, the EU and its Member States to minimise any disruption that may occur should the UK leave the EU without an agreed Withdrawal Agreement and proposes that the Government should build on this work as follows:ldquo. That the Government should publish the UKrsquos Day One Tarf Schedules immediatelyldquo. To allow businesses to prepare for the operation of those tarfs, that the Government should seek an extension of the Article  process to .pm on May nd , at which point the UK would leave the EUldquo. Thereafter, in a spirit of co-operation and in order to begin discussions on the Future Relationship, the Government should offer a further set of mutual standstill agreements with the EU and Member States for an agreed period ending no later than th December , during which period the UK would pay an agreed sum equivalent to its net EU contributions and satisfy its other public international law obligations andldquo. The Government should unilaterally guarantee the rights of EU citizens resident in the UK.It was signed by Damian Green, Iain Duncan Smith, Nicky Morgan, Steve Baker, Jacob Rees-Mogg, Simon Hart and the DUPrsquos Nigel Dodds..pm.pm.pmFirst Minister Nicola Sturgeon said: ldquoNow that the Prime Ministerrsquos deal has been resoundingly defeated for a second time, what is abundantly clear is that the UK Government and Parliament have been unable to turn the result of the  referendum into a workable or deliverable plan to leave the European Union.ldquoThe votes now scheduled for the coming days will now give Parliament the chance to definitively reject the catastrophe of no-deal and to allow for more time for a sensible way forward to be found ndash but the Prime Minister should definitively rule out no-deal, instead of offering a free vote on the issue.ldquoRuling out lsquono-dealrsquo and extending Article  would stop the clock on Brexit and enable another referendum on EU membership to be held. We will support any such referendum, provided it has the option to remain in the EU on the ballot paper.ldquoScotlandrsquos needs and voice have been ignored by the UK Government throughout the Brexit process, and today a handful of DUP MPs held more sway over Scotlandrsquos future than our own national Parliament ndash that demonstrates more clearly than ever that the case for Scotland becoming an independent country has never been stronger..pmDanish Prime Minister Lars Lokke Rasmussen said he would ldquointensy his countryrsquos no-deal preparations.He wrote on Twitter: ldquoDeeply saddened by the outcome of the #Brexit vote this evening.ldquoDespite clear EU assurances on the backstop, we now face a chaotic #NoDeal #Brexit scenario. And time is almost up. We will intensy our #NoDeal preparation..pmIan Blackford, the SNP Westminster leader, called the vote an ldquoutter humiliation for the Prime Minister, adding ldquowe are now in a crisis.He told Sky News: ldquoWe must tomorrow remove any prospect of no deal. No deal would be disastrous.ldquoThere is a real threat to jobs on a massive scalethere is no deal, the threat to the supply of medicines and food.ldquoWe must in the first instance take our responsibilities in getting that risk off the table..pmIt is expected that a plan for the Irish border in the event of a no-deal Brexit, as well as the no-deal tarf schedule, will be published on Wednesday morning..pm.pmBrexit was about taking back control, instead the UK spiralled out of control. Only cross-party cooperation putting Country first, can end this mess. If this happens we will fully engage. #BrexitDeal pic kseavUwYnpmdash Guy VerhofstadtMarch , .pmAsked about Wednesdayrsquos vote on whether the UK should leave the EU without a deal on March , DUP Westminster leader Nigel Dodds told Sky News: ldquoOur position is simple.ldquoThe best way to get a deal you can actually vote for is to keep the threat of a no-deal on the table.ldquoOnce you take that threat off you are bound to be offered terms which are less advantageous in the sure and certain knowledge that the other side have that yoursquore not going to walk away. So, itrsquos totally self-defeating, itrsquos utterly counter-productive..pmShould the UK hand in a reasoned request for an extension, I expect a credible and convincing justication. The #EU will consider the request and decide by unanimity. The smooth ing of the EU institutions needs to be ensured.mdash Mark RutteMarch , .pmA Downing Street source said the Prime Minister had not discussed resigning with her team and said it ldquoremains the case that the Commons recently expressed its confidence in the Government.The source said: ldquoIt still remains the case that the House of Commons as a whole has quite recently expressed its confidence in the Government, which is of course led by the Prime Minister..pm.pmAsked why Mrs May did not announce her resignation on Tuesday night, deputy Conservative chairman James Cleverley said: ldquoBecause the Prime Minister has made it clear she regards this as her professional duty to deliver the Brexit that people voted for in .He told the BBC: ldquoWersquove not been through a situation before where wersquove been extricating ourselves from the EU. These are unprecedented times. Judging things on past norms is no longer the case.ldquoThe Prime Minister is having to navigate a very, very dficult course through the unique set of circumstances we are being presented with..pmLiberal Democrat leader Sir Vince Cable suggested Tories may now move against the PM.He told the Press Association: ldquoIrsquom afraid her authority is completely shot. How she can continue with the same plan of action is incomprehensible.ldquoSomething has got to give. I should imagine the Conservative Party will just put an end to this..pmChuka Umunna, who quit Labour to form the Independent group of breakaway MPs, said ldquothe juryrsquos out on whether the vote made a second referendum result more likely.He told BBC News: ldquoUltimately with gridlock in this place continuing itrsquos hard to see how you resolve the gridlock without referring it back to the people..pm.pm.pmJacob Rees-Mogg, chairman of the European Research Group of Brexiteer MPs, said ldquothe problem with the deal was that it didnrsquot deliver on the commitment to leave the EU cleanly and that the backstop would have kept us in the customs union and de facto in the single market..pm.pmA spokesman for European Council president Donald Tusk said: ldquoWe regret the outcome of tonightrsquos vote and are disappointed that the UK Government has been unable to ensure a majority for the Withdrawal Agreement agreed by both parties in November.ldquoOn the EU side we have done all that is possible to reach an agreement. Given the additional assurances provided by the EU in December, January and yesterday, it is dficult to see what more we can do.ldquoIf there is a solution to the current impasse, it can only be found in London..pmLondon Mayor Sadiq Khan said: ldquoI welcome tonightrsquos vote to reject the Governmentrsquos bad Brexit deal.ldquoThe Prime Minister needs to put our city and our country first, and withdraw Article .ldquoItrsquos time to give the British public the final say on Brexit..pmThe EU has done everything it can to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line. The impasse can only be solved in the #UK. Our ldquono-deal preparations are now more important than ever before.mdash Michel BarnierMarch , The EUrsquos chief negotiator Michel Barnier has said no-deal preparations ldquoare now more important than ever before following the vote.He tweeted: ldquoThe EU has done everything it can to help get the Withdrawal Agreement over the line. The impasse can only be solved in the #UK.ldquoOur lsquono-dealrsquo preparations are now more important than ever before..pmLabour leader Jeremy Corbyn, raising a point of order, said: ldquoThe Government has been defeated again by an enormous majority.ldquoThey must now accept their deal is clearly dead and does not have the support of this House.ldquoQuite clearly, no-deal must be taken off the table.Mr Corbyn said the Commons has to come together with a proposal that could be negotiated, adding Labour will put forward its plans again.He suggested a general election should also be held..pm.pmShe then set out the next steps in the Brexit process, confirming there would be a vote tomorrow on whether MPs back a no deal exit.The PM said: ldquoJust like the referendum there are strongly held and equally legitimate views on both sides. For that reason I can confirm this it will be a free vote on this side of the House..pmMrs May stressed her responsibilities for Northern Ireland, where Stormont is still suspended.She said: ldquoIrsquom conscious of my duties as Prime Minister of Great Britain and Northern Ireland and the potential damage to the union that leaving without a deal could do, when one part of our country is without a devolved government..pmAnnouncing the free vote, Mrs May told MPs: ldquoThis is an issue of grave importance for the future of our country.ldquoJust like the referendum there are strongly held and equally legitimate views on both sides.ldquoFor that reason, I can confirm that this will be a free vote on this side of the House.The Prime Minister said she had ldquopersonally struggled with this choice but the best way to leave was ldquoin an orderly way with a deal..pmTheresa May said she ldquoprofoundly regrets the decision this House has taken tonight.The Prime Minister made a statement after the result of the vote was read out, saying: ldquoI continue to believe that by far the best outcome is the UK leaves the European Union in orderly fashion with a deal.ldquoAnd that the deal we have negotiated is the best and indeed only deal available..pmIf the Commons declines to approve a no-deal Brexit, a vote on extending Article  will take place on Thursday, said Mrs May..pmThe motion will say that the Commons declines to leave the EU without a deal, said Mrs May..pmFollowing the defeat of her Brexit deal in the second ldquomeaningful vote, Prime Minister Theresa May told the House of Commons that she will grant a free vote to Conservative MPs in a vote on Wednesday on whether the UK should leave the EU without a deal on March ..MPs have rejected the Governmentrsquos Brexit deal by  votes to , majority ..pmOpposition MPs voting against the Prime Ministerrsquos deal have tweeted to say they have been joined by a large number of Conservatives and the lobby is ldquoabsolutely rammed.Labourrsquos Jo Stevens tweeted: ldquoPM will lose this vote resoundingly. Our voting lobby is rammed.The SNPrsquos Pete Wishart added: ldquoGovernment going to get gubbed.
