title: astonishing-level-of-dog-dirt-on-sports-pitches-in-tranent
story: Sports clubs are working alongside East Lothian Council in a bid to reduce the number of people failing to clear up after their pets.Three blackspots in the area have been identied ndash Polson Park, Meadowmill and Ross High playing fields ndash and Councillor Colin McGinn described the amount of dog fouling as ldquoastonishing.He said: ldquoWhat is currently happening is the rugby club and Tranent Colts, who use Ross High playing fields, they have to send out a group of coaches or officials to walk the pitches and clear up the mess before they start playing. Runners at Meadowmill, or even the cricket club, are having to go out and make sure the training areas are clean before they start.ldquoFolk want to just turn up and get fit or improve their wellbeing without having to resort to clearing up dog mess before any activity.ldquoIt is irresponsible and pretty uncaring from people.Mr McGinn, who lives in Tranent, visited Meadowmill alongside representatives from ious East Lothian Council departments, including environmental health.The councillor described the situation as ldquoa disgrace, with a campaign to be launched in the coming weeks.Adam Hook, head coach at Ross High RFC, agreed it was a major problem.He said: ldquoIt is really frustrating. You can imagine we are trying to get warmed up and someone stops playing after spotting dog mess on the pitch. Someone then has got to take time out to clear it up and it impacts the warm up or during the game.Mr Hook was keen to see more regular patrols carried out by dog wardens in an attempt to catch irresponsible pet owners.He added: ldquoThey should hit them in the pocket and seethey do it again.ldquoIt is just total laziness. I know lots of people with dogs that would never dream of doing it.Phil Purves, chairman of Tranent Colts, agreed that it was a problem which was getting worse.He told the Courier: ldquoIt is very frustrating.ldquo[Clearing dog fouling] is something we have done pretty much all the time we have coached but it is out of control now.ldquoWe had a game two weeks ago and had to clean up  piles off one pitch.The club has recently bought a dog fouling bin to be put near the playing fields in a bid to encourage owners to clean up after their pets.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoThe council has noted an increase in complaints about dog fouling in recent weeks, particularly within grass sports areas and school grounds.ldquoOptions are currently being considered as to how best to tackle this situation and will be communicated in due course. In the meantime, all dog owners are reminded of their legal and moral responsibility to clean up after their dog and dispose of the waste properly.

title: new-affordable-homes-in-ormiston-approved
story: The  new homes off the villagersquos Tynemount Road will be part of a larger development by Walker Homes. In total,  properties are being built at the site.East Lothian Councilrsquos planning department gave the scheme the go-ahead last week, with  affordable houses and  flats to be built on the site.The housing will be a mix of council homes and mid-market rentals.Each of the new homes will be classed as affordable housing, with the  flats comprising of six semi-detached two-storey flatted buildings with two bedrooms, and four semi-detached two-storey flats with one bedroom in each.Ten of the houses will be semi-detached, with three terraced properties and two detached homes.Sixteen of the properties will have three bedrooms, with the remaining house containing two bedrooms.A spokeswoman for East Lothian Council said: ldquoWe are delighted to be creating more affordable housing units in Ormiston.ldquoAt least  of these will be new council houses.ldquoWe are currently in discussion with another affordable housing provider to potentially deliver  of the units for mid-market rent, creating a mixed tenure development to meet the ied needs of our communities.Meanwhile, more than pound, will be split between the villagersquos primary school and Ross High School in Tranent to ensure that there is sufficient educational capacity to serve the housing.A sum of pound, will go towards Ormiston Primary School, with a further pound, going to the secondary school.Haddington and Lammermuir ward member Councillor Shamin Akhtar was delighted with the additional housing. She said: ldquoIt is good news that permission has been granted for  council houses and  affordable homes for rent in Ormiston.ldquoThese are much-needed homes and will be welcomed by the local community.

title: longniddry-schoolgirl-meets-nicola-sturgeon-over-bubbles-campaign
story: Ellie McIntyre champions Longniddry Primary Schoolrsquos Bubbles Beat Balloons campaign, which encourages people to blow eco-friendly bubbles as an alternative to releasing balloons at public celebrations or tribute events.The youngster wrote to First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, who invited the eight-year-old to the Scottish Parliament to discuss the scheme further.The P pupil received a letter from Ms Sturgeonrsquos office highlighting the importance of young people being involved in developing initiatives and taking them forward.Ellie, who lives in Tranent, said: ldquoIt was exciting to meet Nicola Sturgeon and she let me have a selfie with her.ldquoI was happy she was able to sign our pledge.The youngster was joined at Holyrood by her mum Pauline, as well as her class teacher Yvonne Hart.The group were given a tour of the building, before meeting Ms Sturgeon and sitting in at First Ministerrsquos Questions. Ellie took a framed campaign certicate and Ms Sturgeon signed the lsquoBubbles Beat Balloonsrsquo pledge.Miss Hart added: ldquoThe First Minister was clearly impressed by Ellie and was keen to sign our campaign.ldquoFor her to make time in her busy schedule like this was amazing!The environmental campaign was launched by the school, which is home to  pupils, last summer.After participating in a One Planet One Future project and watching the BBCrsquos Blue Planet  programme ndash which highlighted the devastating impact of plastic on wildle and nature ndash the pupils decided to take action.The children learnt that mass balloon releases were often used when celebrating events or for remembering loved ones. So they decided the much-loved childrenrsquos pastime of blowing bubbles was a much more environmentally friendly way of marking special events instead of polluting the planet with latex balloons.The initiative has already been backed by the Marine Conservation Society, as well as East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Ranger Service.Pupils at the school have delivered presentations to local community councillors while a number of local businesses and organisations have signed up to the Bubbles Beat Balloons pledge.The campaign was part of the schoolrsquos work towards achieving gold status as a Rights Respecting School. Longniddry is the only primary school in East Lothian to hold Gold Right Respecting Schools status.The UNICEF UK award recognises the schoolrsquos work embedding childrenrsquos rights in its policy, practices and culture.Sheona Skinner, headteacher, said: ldquoIrsquom incredibly proud of Ellie using her pupil voice to continue our schoolrsquos campaign. Having the First Ministerrsquos support has widened awareness of the initiative and will hopefully encourage more people to become involved. It was a special occasion for Ellie and for everyone involved in Longniddry Primary School.

title: pavements-to-be-dug-up-over-next-nine-months-as-ultrafast-broadband-comes-to-musselburgh
story: The company says that this will help bring ldquoultrafast broadband speeds of up to Mbps ndash the fastest widely available speeds in the UK ndash to the area.Speaking at a meeting of Musselburgh and Inveresk Community Council last week, Eddie McGuigan, the companyrsquos community liaison officer, said that the project to lay fibre cable underground would get under way in mid-April.He said: ldquoWe will be in Musselburgh itself for the next eight or nine months, certainly until Christmas time.He added: ldquoThe idea is to give everyone the opportunity to get the cable.ldquoItrsquos a great thing for businesses and homes that use a lot of internet and wi-fi.ldquoThe downside to that is we are going to have to do some work on your pavements. We do about  metres a day, so wherever we are, we come and go quite quickly.He added that trenches would be created and high-pressure air used to blow a high fibre cable through.Mr McGuigan said that small cabinets, which are connection points for the network to residentsrsquo homes, would also be ldquodotted around areas.He stressed: ldquoWe donrsquot put them in corners or outside peoplersquos front windows. They canrsquot be in the line of sight of someone and we keep them away from driveways.ldquoAll the work we do is on adopted council land, so we speak to the council beforehand and get the notices in.ldquoIf we need to go into any private estates, shared drives and private roads, we seek way leave which is permission to go in there. If we donrsquot get that, we donrsquot go in.Small diggers will be used to carry out the work and soft areas will be dug up by hand.Mr McGuigan added: ldquoThe barriers will go upthere is a driveway and we will make sure itrsquos covered. We have ramps to go over, so everyone can get in and out.ldquoWe will dig up the pavement ndash unfortunately there will be a scar. We do it the same colour as the pavement. If itrsquos slabs, we will lt them up and put them back down. If itrsquos mono block, we have special mono blocking teams. If itrsquos just concrete, we use the same colour concrete. We will have multiple crews in multiple areas.He said that letters with his details would be sent out to local residents, adding: ldquoIf there is anyone on night sht, we will work round about that.Mr McGuigan said the work would start at the Fisherrow Harbour end of Musselburgh, with Wallyford the next phase, then Tranent and Port Seton.Information events will be held and a pop-up gazebo with information will also be located in the town centre.A company spokesman added: ldquoWith a Mbps connection, files, films and games become unbelievably quick to stream, download and upload.

title: first-dunbar-parkrun-to-be-held-this-weekend
story: The Lochend Woods Parkrun starts on Saturday morning, with runners covering a five-kilometre course in Hallhill.A trial took place on Saturday morning and Lynne Lewis, event director, was pleased to say things had gone smoothly ahead of the real thing starting at .am on Saturday.She said: ldquoThe parkrun trial happened in the most horrendous conditions.ldquoWe had  runners who braved the conditions and a lot were families, with mums and dads running with their children.ldquoWe tested all the kit on Saturday, tested the timer, uploading the times and that was all done on a test system.ldquoWe are expecting, hopefully, not too big a crowd ndash we could get  people running.Parkrun was formed in England more than  years ago by a group of friends who met each weekend for a jog.Until earlier this year, there were no parkrun events in East Lothian but Dunbar is set to join Meadowmill, near Tranent, in flying the flag for the county.Participants can either walk or jog the route, with a team of volunteers working hard for more than six months to see the event created.Mrs Lewis, who has taken part in more than  parkruns, said: ldquoIt is really about getting the message out there that parkrun is for everyone.The course starts at the running track outside Hallhill Sports Centre and is a figure-of-eight shape, comprising two laps of . kilometres.The course heads west away from the centre on tarmac paths around the sports pitches, then s towards the centre and heads into Lochend Woods, before ing towards the centre and repeating itself.Funding for the initiative has come from a number of local organisations, including the townrsquos running club, community council and Rotary club, as well as Viridor, EDF ndash Torness, Team East Lothian and Improve My Running.For more information, go to parkrun.org.uk lochendwoods

title: mueller-ends-russia-investigation-what-happens-next
story: Herersquos what to expect next:What happens when the investigation ends Mr Mueller had to submit a report of some kind. It could be bare-bones.Justice Department regulations require only that Mr Mueller give the Attorney General a confidential report that explains the decisions to pursue or decline prosecutions. That could be as simple as a bullet point list or as fulsome as a report running hundreds of pages.What will the Attorney General do William Barr said he envisions two reports, and only one for congressional and public consumption.Mr Barr has said he takes seriously the ldquoshall be confidential part of the regulations governing Mr Muellerrsquos report. He has noted that department protocol says internal memos explaining charging decisions should not be released.During his confirmation hearing, Mr Barr said he would draft, after Mr Mueller turned in his report, a second one for the chairman and ranking members of the House and Senate Judiciary committees. But the regulations provide little guidance for what such a report would say.The Attorney General is required only to say the investigation has concluded and describe or explain any times when he or Deputy Attorney General Rod Rosenstein decided an action Mr Mueller proposed ldquowas so inappropriate or unwarranted that it should not be pursued.In a letter Mr Barr sent on Friday to the four members of the two Judiciary committees, he said there were ldquono such instances. He also said he may be in a position to advise them of Mr Muellerrsquos conclusions ldquoas soon as this weekend.Mr Barr indicated that he expects to use his report to share the results of Mr Muellerrsquos investigation with the public, which the regulations allow him to do. But he has hedged on specics and said his plans could change after speaking with Mr Mueller and Mr Rosenstein.Will Donald Trump be able to see the report It is unclear whether Donald Trump will ask to see the report and under what circumstances he or his attorneys might be able to view it, especially because the document is meant to be confidential for Justice Department leadership.Mr Mueller reports to the Justice Department, not the White House.Mr Barr said at his confirmation hearing that he would not permit White House interference in the investigation. But he has also voiced an expansive view of executive power in which the president s as the countryrsquos chief law enforcement officer and has wide latitude in giving directives to the FBI and Justice Department.Democrats could seize on any disclosure to the president to argue that the report is not confidential and should be immediately provided to them as well.Can Democrats in Congress subpoena Mr Mueller and his report Yes. The chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, Representative Jerrold Nadler, has said as much.ldquoWe could subpoena the final report. We could subpoena Mueller and ask him in front of the committee what was in your final report. Those are things we could do, Mr Nadler told ABCrsquos This Week in October.But Mr Trump, as the leader of the executive branch, could direct the Justice Department to defy the subpoena, setting the stage for a court fight that would almost certainly go to the Supreme Court.

title: pm-admits-third-vote-on-her-brexit-deal-may-not-take-place-next-week
story: The Prime Minister wrote to MPs warning thatthere is insufficient support for her Withdrawal Agreement in the coming days that she could seek an extension to Britainrsquos EU membership beyond the European Parliament elections.It came after the DUP ndash whose support will be crucialthe Government is to win ndash indicated they would not back her deal, with the partyrsquos deputy leader Nigel Dodds lamenting the PMrsquos failure to secure any changes to the Northern Ireland backstop while in Brussels.ldquoNothing has changed as far as the Withdrawal Agreement is concerned. We will not accept any deal which poses a long-term risk to the constitutional and economic integrity of the United Kingdom, he said.Mrs May sought to soften her approach in her letter to parliamentarians, offering to hold talks with MPs and thanking those who have backed her plan previously.And she laid out the choices available to the Commons after she agreed a delay to Brexit with EU leaders in Brussels on Thursday night.The PM said the UK could revoke Article  leave without a deal ask for an extension beyond April her deal is rejected or not voted on or leave on May it is finally approved.Mrs May wrote: ldquoIf it appears that there is not sufficient support to bring the deal back next week, or the House rejects it again, we can ask for another extension before  April ndash but that will involve holding European Parliament elections.ldquoIf it appears that there is sufficient support and the Speaker permits it, we can bring the deal back next week andit is approved we can leave on  May.It came as ministers moved to try to head off an attempt by MPs to seize control of Commons business in a bid to secure a ldquosofter Brexit.A cross-party group of pro-EU MPs claimed they had the numbers to force a series of ldquoindicative votes on alternatives to Mrs Mayrsquos Brexit deal.But Business Secretary Greg Clark said the Government was prepared to enable Parliament to express a view on the ious optionsMrs Mayrsquos deal is rejected by the Commons for a third time next week.Defeat for the Government on Monday on the amendment ndash tabled by former ministers Sir Oliver Letwin and Dominic Grieve and Labour MP Hilary Benn ndash would be a further humiliation for Mrs May.If the amendment is passed, it would pave the way for a series of ldquoindicative votes in the House on Wednesday, effectively taking control of the Brexit process out of the hands of the Government.Elsewhere it emerged that Tory former foreign secretary Boris Johnson met Mrs May for talks twice this week, including on Friday.Mr Johnson is said to have asked the PM how she intended to change her approach, and she reportedly set out plans to restructure the Department for Exiting the European Union.Hundreds of thousands of supporters of a second referendum will march through central London on Saturday, where Labourrsquos deputy leader Tom Watson is expected to say he will vote for the PMrsquos dealit is put to the people.Meanwhile Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn, who has been reluctant to throw his full weight behind a so-called Peoplersquos Vote, will be campaigning in the North West of England.As Mrs May battles to stay in Number , Prisons Minister Rory Stewart said replacing her would not help the situation.ldquoI would rather she stayed because I donrsquot believe that changing Theresa May for someone  is going to resolve this problem, he told BBC Tworsquos Newsnight.ldquoThe problems are deep in the wounds of the vote, Parliament, the European Union ndash itrsquos not about a single inidual.

title: call-to-crack-down-on-unqualified-scots-identifying-as-electricians
story: Tory Jamie Halcro Johnston described the lack of regulation in the profession as an ldquoanomaly and has urged the Scottish Government to take action to ensure the title of electrician is protected in law.Over  professions are currently protected in law, including registered gas engineers, but not electricians.Mr Halcro Johnston said that he will introduce a membersrsquo bill to the Scottish Parliament aiming to address the issue.In a debate on the subject in October, MSPs from across the parties at Holyrood gave their support for providing protection of title.Mr Halcro Johnston said: ldquoFor too long, the Scottish Government has dithered around the regulation of electricians.ldquoIt has been discussed and discussed again, without any real commitments ever seeing the light of day.ldquoWhen I speak to people about this campaign, the first reaction is usually surprise that anyone can call themselves an electrician without any qualication.ldquoWhen so many other trades and professions are regulated, it seems the position of electricians is more of an anomaly than anything .ldquoMost people donrsquot consult electricians on a regular basis and arenrsquot always confident about the qualications of people they employ. This should provide some additional protection to consumers.ldquoElectrical safety is vitally important. Every year, there are fatalities caused by electric shocks and fires caused by electrical mals. It is important that people carrying out electrical work are qualied and able to do so.ldquoI was pleased to get so much support from across the political parties when this was debated back in October and I would hope that support would carry across to introducing a Bill on the subject.Skills Minister Jamie Hepburn said: ldquoThe serious concerns raised about electricians are being considered fully and we are committed to continuing to work in partnership with all stakeholders.ldquoDuring a debate in Parliament in October last year, I offered to meet with any MSPs to discuss these issues further. Whilst others have made contact, Mr Halcro Johnston has not taken up this offer.ldquoFollowing calls for further regulation, we formed the Electricians Working Group to bring the industry together and attempt to build consensus for a way forward.ldquoAn independent analysis of research, leading to a risk assessment and business case on the way forward, is due to be presented to the Scottish Government later in March.

title: we-are-f-says-official-report-on-impact-of-brexit-on-rural-scotland
story: A document published by Scottish Rural Actionfeatured a side banner on page four with the statement.It was one of a number of banners attributed to participants in a workshop which asked them to imagine what newspaper headlines they might expect to see after Brexit.Amanda Burgauer, SRA chairwoman, said that the exercise had been used as an ldquoicebreaker and that several of the participants had used ldquoearthy language in describing their feelings towards Brexit.The comments are only explained on the following page, saying they had been put forward by those taking part in the workshop event.Ms Burgauer said that she would flag up the ldquodesign and layout issue with the SRA design team.The Scottish Government has said that although the SRA report was funded through its Brexit Stakeholder Fund, it had no editorial role.The report will be launched at an SRA event with cabinet secretaries Mike Russell and Richard Lochhead in Elgin on Monday.Its findings also detailed the potential impact of Brexit on rural Scotland, suggesting that it could lead to ldquost century clearances, with a loss of freedom of movement resulting in signicant depopulation.Further concerns raised in the report, taken from conversations with rural communities, also included the risk of EU funding being lost post-Brexit and potential damage to social cohesion.Speaking about the report overall, Ms Burgauer said: ldquoThis report is about giving voice to a rural point of view that is rooted in Scotlandrsquos people and places, rather than its rural industries.She added: ldquoThere is widespread anger and frustration across rural Scotland, but that anger isnrsquot solely about Brexit.ldquoIt was clear from workshop discussions that Brexit is compounding long standing concerns about rural equity and fragility.ldquoBrexit was described as the lsquostraw that breaks rural Scotlandrsquos backrsquo, with people pointing to structural fragilities across rural communities.ldquoParticipants generally believed that an historic over-reliance on EU funding to lsquoprop uprsquo rural areas makes rural Scotland particularly exposed to future loss of EU support.Speaking ahead of the reportrsquos launch, Constitutional Relations Secretary Mike Russell said: ldquoThe Scottish Government is committed to ensuring the voices of rural communities are heard and I commend Scottish Rural Action for the work it has done to achieve this.ldquoThe findings in this report are stark. Taking Scotland out of the EU against our will removes us from a market which is eight times bigger than the UK alone.ldquoRural communities are deeply worried about the impact of Brexit on their lives. From funding and trade to community le and the workforce, many believe the effects will be nothing short of catastrophic.ldquoThis is sadly yet another example of just how damaging Brexit will be for Scotland.A UK Government spokesman said: ldquoThriving rural areas with strong, sustainable economies and vibrant communities will continue to be a priority for the UK Government when we leave the EU.ldquoWe have committed to establishing a UK Shared Prosperity Fund, which will cover Scotland, to increase productivity in areas where the local economies are furthest behind.ldquoWe have also confirmed that we will maintain the same cash total in funds for farm support until the end of the Parliament.

title: one-visitor-set-aside-15m-for-a-three-day-highlands-tour
story: Scotlandrsquos new breed of high-rolling visitors may be here on holiday but most of us wonrsquot see them ndash for these are not your typical Royal Mile tourists.Instead, some of the worldrsquos wealthiest people are pouring millions into hiring castles to stay in, chartering yachts and helicopters to whisk them from distilleries to golf courses, and private dinners with lairds and lords demanding unique experiences that, it turns out, money really can buy.Scotland is in the midst of a luxury holiday boom, and attracting rising numbers of enormously wealthy visitors desperate to indulge in adventures that most Scots would never imagine.The sums of money involved can be eye-watering. One case Chinese visitor is said to have set aside pound. million for a three-day tour of the Highlands.While that is at the extreme end of the scale, insiders say itrsquos not unusual for ldquoaverage visitors to spend pound, per person for a week, while others can easily spend double that on a single shopping spree at the House of Bruar.One luxury tour operator said: ldquoThe sky is the limit. A lot of whatrsquos going on is very discreet ndash most people donrsquot realise the amount of money flowing through the country.In many cases the millionaire tourist is looking to pay top dollar to share a dram with a whisky expert, play golf on a remote Hebridean course that most Scots have never heard of, or join scallop ers and fishermen off the west coast, rather than rub shoulders with the hoi polloi at the usual tourist haunts.According to a report from Allied Market Research, the global luxury market is projected to be the fastest-growing area of the tourism sector, expected to be worth ,bn by .A key element is said to be demand from high-end travellers to gain deeper experiences of the places they visit, avoiding tourist hotspots in favour of highly-personalised trips.VisitScotland has suggested income from ldquohigh-net-worth iniduals is forecast to rise by around % a year. Chief executive Malcolm Roughead said: ldquoIt is important that we encourage the tourism industry to provide world-class service, facilities, events and attractions to keep up with ever-changing consumer demands and ensure visitors continue to have memorable experiences.While luxury tour operators have always had a place in Scotlandrsquos tourist sector, there are signs of a growing response to rising demand, from hotels offering bespoke packages, to firms specialising in personalised itineraries and road trip specialists who send tourists off in Aston Martins to tackle the North Coast  ndash at around pound, a pop.Last week, five-star Edinburgh hotel The Glasshouse became the latest to join the luxury ldquoexperience market with a two-night Elite Whisky Experience ndash costing pound, a head.That buys two nights for two people at the hotelrsquos lavish Islay Suite overlooking Calton Hill, meals ndash including a seven-course whisky tasting dinner ndash guided tour of a distillery and the chance to explore the hotelrsquos selection of  whiskies with its whisky ambassador on hand to help with selections.One company, Bravo Whisky Golf, which specialises in tailor-made golf packages which whisk visitors from course to course by chartered plane, is offering three nights in an Islay hotel and chartered plane to watch this yearrsquos Open at Royal Portrush, plus a distillery tour and a round at Machrie Golf Links ndash for around pound,.ldquoTypically, clients will spend , to , per head for golf, accommodation, flights, meals and drinks, said Neil Scott Johnson, who co-founded Bravo Whisky Golf with his friend Paul Geddes. ldquoThese people have done Carnoustie, St Andrews and Turnberry and are looking for new experiences. They want to get home and say lsquoThe plane landed on this island beach and we played an amazing Old Tom Morris links coursersquo.Among its tours is a -day ldquoOdyssey involving  flights and  golf courses ndash mostly on Hebridean islands or in the Highlands. Thrown in is dinner with a whisky aficionado and an evening on board the former royal yacht Britannia.Wealthy visitors swoop into the country on board private jets and book up entire country houses or castles for their party at eye-watering costs, says Simeon Rosset, who runs Rosset Bespoke Butlers and is often called on to arrange high-end accommodation and staff for well-heeled visitors.ldquoYou would never recognise them ndash theyrsquore not travelling around in Rolls-Royces, theyrsquore not that obvious. But they will go out on shopping trips to the House of Bruar and spend pound,, he said. ldquoTherersquos huge money travelling through Scotland. A group of  staying for a week can easily spend poundm.If anything, he adds, there is a shortage of luxury produce for them to spend their money on. ldquoThis is high-level tourism and we need to persuade people to join in and provide what they want, he said.Specialist companies like Edinburgh-based Dream Escape promise ldquoluxurious private cruises to exclusive access to historic castles and other elegant accommodation combined with Michelin-star dining, with chauffeur-driven tours, adventure activities and private helicopters.However, as well as the established players and the London-based high-end agencies, a new breed of ldquograss-roots operators is also finding a niche within a massively wealthy market.Chris Hunter of Luxury Concierge Scotland was running a chauffeur business when he spotted demand from wealthy visitors seeking ldquosomething dferent.He now organises bespoke tours, arranging castle accommodation, supercars for hitting the North Coast  and gourmet dining.ldquoI have a couple coming in June who want to tour in a car, so Irsquom organising a Porsche  for them. They want to stay in a castle on the west coast, and then therersquos the obligatory helicopter tour, so theyrsquoll go from the castle over to Skye for a distillery visit, he said.ldquoThese are people who can do spas and luxury hotels anywhere. What they want in Scotland are those experiences they canrsquot get anywhere .French-born Solveig Kerdranvat and her fianceacute Jonny Stage are the modern face of luxury travel in Scotland ndash images on their Sandgrouse website show her posing in a kilt gazing at island moorland, or ldquohunting-shooting style beside a Land Rover.The helicopter they use to ferry their clients on ldquodistillery crawls ndash involving stops at multiple distilleries across Scotland in a single day ndash features a familiar registration, G-TRMP, and was once used by Donald Trump.Sandgrouse tours can hit pound, per person, while some special requests can prove particularly demanding.ldquoPeople are looking out-of-the-box experiences, says Mr Stage. ldquoFor example, we take them to the Glenfinnan viaduct at just the right time to see the steam train passing. So theyrsquore hovering above it rather than standing in the car park with everyone .Wealthy tourists want to be able to impress their friends by doing something unique, he adds.ldquoThey want to come to Scotland and be best buddies with the fishermen on the west coast, or have a great day ing for scallops or with a ghillie whorsquos been on an estate for  years.ldquoThen they go back to New York and talk about an amazing day with a guy on the hill who showed them the stags.ldquoThatrsquos what luxury travel is about.TIE PIECEA recovering global economy is fuelling a worldwide luxury travel sector currently said to be worth  billionn.However, Scotland is hardly a new destination for the worldrsquos super rich ndash after all, the Queen made a point of spending her summer break cruising the west coast in Britannia and staying at Balmoral, while Skibo Castle near Dornoch has been a retreat for the rich for decades.Two years ago, Russian billionaire Roman Abramovich took a west coast break when he moored his super yacht, Eclipse, in the Clyde.Last year, billionaire mathematician James Simons parked his pound million super yacht at ious locations during a summer tour of Scotland. His net worth is estimated at poundbn.Meanwhile, some of the richest people in the world have opted to create a more permanent holiday home.The billionaire ruler of Dubai, Sheikh Mohammed Bin Rashid al-Maktoum, has taken over a ,-acre holiday estate in Inverinate, Wester Ross, and Russian drinks billionaire Yuri Shefler bought Tulchan Estate ndash a ,-acre property  miles south of Inverness said to boast some of the best salmon fishing in Europe.

title: Rosemary Goring  The shunning of Kelman  how strange it is  how strange
story: To mark the th anniversary of winning the Booker Prize with How Late It Was, How Late, Kelman recently gave an interview to the New Statesman. That novel was widely lambasted for its so-called profanity, which so shocked one judge, Rabbi Julia Neuberger, she stormed out of the meeting. ldquoOver my dead body was the mildest of her comments.About a year ago, Kelman finished a new novel which, he revealed, has still to find a publisher. After a long period with Secker  Warburg and Hamish Hamilton, he moved to Canongate with his last two books, That Was a Shiver, and Dirt Road, both of which were well received. But this new manuscript languishes, untouched and apparently unloved. Nobody, it seems, even in his own heath, is willing to make a decent offer for it.With some writers, you could understand. Thanks to technology that registers every sale, publisherscan see exactly how bankable their books are. When approached by a writer, they can track their performance at the click of a mouse. If this is healthy, they are far more likely to pounce on them thanthe novelistrsquos sales have not even covered their advance, leaving a publisher effectively in the red.This does not, of course, mean the novelist is no good. Sometimes it indicates the reverse. Literary fiction is a highly raried taste ndash as it always was. Only the most fortunate of such writers make a good living from the proceeds of books alone. For most it is a struggle to get by, hence the number finding shelter teaching on creative writing courses. Kelman himself went down that route for a time, but you can be fairly sure thathis books had sold like airport bestsellers, there would have been no need to find a financial cushion.In what you can only call the good old days, a young writer like Graham Greene would be given considerable leeway with his early books by a publisher confident that one day he would reward their patience. Today, there is no slack in the system, no time to nurture or take the long view. You are only as good as your last book. And in the case of someone like Kelman, whose readership is a mere fraction of those interested in serious fiction, that spells trouble.Why do most of those who leap on every title by Julian Barnes or Rose Tremain often not bother with Kelman  Undoubtedly, the furore over his Booker winner damaged his reputation, not only in the rest of the UK, but also here. Kelman, however, suspects there is a more fundamental and disturbing reason. He believes that English publishers are ldquokeeping a lid on Scottish writers, by dismissing them as a genre. They would rather publish mediocre English novelists, he says, than good Scottish ones.Read more: Kelman: British establishment is keeping a lid on Scottish writingThere are enough excellent Scottish novelists reaching print to argue that point, but for me this is a distraction from the main issue. EvenKelman is right and there is anti-Scottish bias among literary publishers, that still does not explain why no Scottish publisher is willing to take him on.Could his new book be too dficult, or tricky  It would seem strangethat were the case, given his long and distinguished backlist in which there is rarely a misfire. The answer is far more likely to be about money, and the state of the book trade in general. In other words, there is no publisher able or prepared to offer a fee commensurate with what a Kelman book is worth. Thatrsquos worth in artistic terms, you understand, not sales. I do not doubt it would be a better investment to publish Diana Gabaldonfilling the coffers is the main objective.But while the kind of books Kelman writes are unlikely to shower a publisher in gold, they would add immeasurably to its lustre. Here is a novelist who has been shortlisted for the Man Booker International Prize, and is a worthy Nobel contender. Indeed, consider this my official plea to the Nobel Prize Literature Committee to read everything Kelman has written and tell us his oeuvre does not equal or surpass many of their laureates.Yet, nobody on his doorstep wants to take his new book. Itrsquos hard to think of another country where its foremost living writer would be treated like this. The only conclusion you can come to is that the world of books has lost it. Irsquod speak even more plainly, but am aware I must moderate my language.

title: herald-diary-tartan-army-traumas
story: OUR children at school stories reminded Michael Gartlan: "A teacher I know was telling her primary class about the th anniversary of the end of World War One back in November and how we should remember the sacrice of all the men and women who suffered in that conflict. One of her six-year-olds proudly announced that her grandad had won a medal in that war. Next day the youngster proudly showed the medal he had won. Printed on it was Congratulations. One year sober."Acting upTHE lovely East Kilbride TV presenter Lorraine Kelly won a huge tax case by claiming that she was an actress playing the part of lovely, bubbly Lorraine Kelly when she appeared on her TV show, which qualied her for a tax break. As a reader emails us: "I do not appear at work as myself but as a person who acts interested. Can I not pay my taxes also "We have to say that in all our dealings with Lorraine she has always been very nice. We once asked why she never slagged anyone off in her autobiography and she told us: "I didnt write anything nasty about anyone in the book. If they were that nasty I just left them out. What better way to annoy them than having them look up the index and finding theyre not there."On airOUR picture of the old underground gents toilet on Glasgows Buchanan Street reminded a reader of Tom Shieldss classic yarn of chatting to the toilet attendant when the premises were still open who was complaining about folk ducking into the toilet to take drugs or sell stolen goods. The attendant came up with the memorable line: "See the things that go on in this toilet, when someone comes in for a s**** its like a breath of fresh air."Once bittenGEORGE Tomlinson gets in touch and feels the need to tell us: "I was reading in The Herald Magazine about the new German Doner Kebab place opening at the old Odeon cinema premises in Glasgow. I was going to take my girlfriend there, but she fears the wurst."Write onTRYING to find someone expressing even a scintilla of sympathy for Prime Minister Theresa May is proving extremely dficult. All we can come up with is award-winning author Adam Kay who grudgingly admits: "As a writer, it would be disingenuous of me to criticise Theresa May for being a week and a half away from a deadline shes known about for three years and having barely started her work on it."Apology acceptedFOLK hoping for a second referendum on leaving the EU have seen the online petition to do so collect over a million backers. As lawyer Joanna Hardy argued: "It would be fantastically British to revoke Article , put the kettle on, apologise to our neighbours for all the fuss, and then vow to never speak of this embarrassment again, except when someone gets drunk at Christmas."Team effortAND even the Scottish football team cannot cheer us up, although one fan did say before the game: "I see the President of Kazakhstan has just resigned. Perhaps someone told him the Tartan Army had taken over the capital and he didnt realise it wasnt a real army."They dontGROWING old continued. A Bearsden reader tells us: "Im officially old. I broke something in the garage and heard myself say for the first time in my le, They dont make things like they used to."

title: tens-of-thousands-of-scottish-children-face-plunge-into-poverty-as-government-targets-missed
story: Targets set by the Scottish Government on reducing child poverty are set to be missed by a large margin, with figures currently rising rather than falling, according to the Resolution Foundation.The thinktank says welfare reforms brought in at Westminster are the biggest problem and warns actions being taken by Scottish ministers are "not remotely large enough" to counteract the effect of poundbn in cuts UK-wide.However it says the Scottish Government could be more radical in looking to mitigate the impact of benefit cuts.The Child Poverty Action Group said childhoods blighted by poverty were "slipping by" and demanded immediate action.Analysis by the Foundation shows that a recent rise in child poverty is set to continue over the next five years, with an additional , children living in poverty after housing costs are taken into account. Currently the Scottish Government says , children are in families affected by relative poverty.The Scottish Government is committed under the Child Poverty Scotland Act to reducing relative child poverty to below  per cent by  and to under  per cent by .But after large falls in the s, the figures have been rising since  and the study says  per cent of children across Scotland will be classed as living in poverty by .The targets set out in the Act will be missed by more than , children according to these estimates.The report blames UK-wide benefit policies for pushing up poverty in Scotland, as well the rest of the UK, including a four-year cash freeze on working age benefits, and the two child limit on welfare payouts. While Scottish Government policies including the Best Start Grant, theCarersrsquo Allowance Supplement and more generous Council Tax Support were not taken into account in the Foundations analysis, it says they are "dwarfed in scale" by the Westminster reforms. The cash freeze alone - announced by former chancellor George Osborne in  - will save the treasury pound.bn in -.The report says the Scottish governments new lsquoIncome Supplementrsquo, due to be introduced by , could help to limit rises in, child poverty or even reduce it,it is sufficiently ambitious. And it says Scottish ministers are right to have set targets, evenit struggles to meet them. The UK Government scrapped child poverty targets in .The Foundation also called for a wider public debate about how support for low-income families should be funded, while warning that half of Mr Osbornes  cuts are yet to take effect.Adam Corlett, Senior Economic Analyst at the Resolution Foundation, said: ldquoChild poverty across Scotland risks reaching a -year high by . This would mean a further , children across Scotland falling below the poverty line, and the Scottish government missing its target to reduce child poverty by over , children.ldquoThis worrying rise in poverty is almost entirely driven by UK-wide decisions, such as the poundbn worth of working-age benefits cuts. But that doesnrsquot mean policy makers in Scotland are powerless to respond.ldquoIf the Scottish government is to meet its ambitious ndash and welcome ndash child poverty reduction targets, it will need to implement much more radical changes to social security than it has done to date.John Dickie, director of the Child Poverty Action Group in Scotland called for immediate action from the Scottish Govedrnment and claimed children could not afford to wait. A pound increase in child benefit could make an immediate impact, he claimed.ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos timetable for a new income supplement fails to reflect the extraordinary increase in child poverty that the country faces," he said."Children in poverty really canrsquot wait until  and beyond for the Scottish Parliament to use its powers to boost family incomes in a substantive way. As time slips by childhoods are slipping by, childhoods that continue to be blighted by the damage poverty wreaks."Action is needed now. An immediate pound top up to child benefit could, for example, lt thousands of children out of poverty and protect many more from hardship.Labour Shadow Cabinet Secretary for the Eradication of Poverty and Inequality Elaine Smith said predictions of a  year high in child poverty levels were "simply horrying".ldquoLabour supported establishing child poverty reduction targets but those targets need to be backed up by government action ndash instead the SNP government has slashed support for local services and refused to bring in an income supplement for the poorest until ," she said. ldquoThe poorest cannot afford to wait that long."

title: annie-lennox-joins-host-of-celebrities-urging-support-for-campaign-to-reverse-brexit
story: Actor Hugh Grant, scientist Brian Cox and comedian David Mitchell were also among those who put their names to the petition with the official D-Day over Brexit just eight days away.Annie Lennox tweeted her support saying: "I have just signed this petition to #RevokeArticle. Itrsquos currently gaining k signatures an hour!"Please join me, sign  share."Some attacked her decision.George Ross responded: "So, to hell with the people who voted out  Some democracy."Sarah Hewlett added: "OMG itrsquos so sad when celebrities feel they have to stick their nose into current affairs, stick with the music, we voted, wersquore leaving, get over it #ticktock not long to go now!!"And a tweeter by the name of CeeJay said :"Why does Remain never realise that circulating luvvie celeb types advocating their cause does NOTHING to convert people to their cause. OMG! Some relative has-been or minor celeb thinks so and so therefore I must too."But the vast majority of responses were positive.Anton W remarked: "Another wise Aberdonian.":Earlier this week, the University of Aberdeen moved to start flying the EU flag for the rest of the month while MPs discuss the future of Brexit.The University of Aberdeen said the move was "not a political statement" adding that it was "a symbolic gesture of solidarity with our European students and staff while the UK Parliament debates the next steps for Brexit".Jamie Pattenden quipped: "Sweet dreams are made of this!"And Anthony Marks said: "Watching the numbers rocket - despite the fact that the site seems to stall from time to time - is one of the things that is currently stopping me from feeling utterly wretched about Brexit."Film star Hugh Grant who supported the petition said: "Ive signed. And it looks like every sane person in the country is signing too."National emergency. Revoke Article  and remain in the EU."TV physicist Brian Cox said: "Ive signed this petition to revoke A and deal with the consequences afterwards - referendum, election, whatever."I have no idea whether these things do any good but after Mays astonishingly irresponsible speech this evening Ill give anything a go."In December, Annie Lennox, Chrissie Hynde, Pink Floydrsquos Nick Mason and Billy Bragg were among numerous artists, bands and music industry leaders who signed an anti-Brexit letter.The open letter, spearheaded by MusicEU, states that ldquoBrexit represents a signicant threat to the UKrsquos Music Industry. Addressed to MPs and the Prime Minister, it called for the British government to seek an alternative to Brexit.Irsquove signed this and, now I know that #@theresa_may# is on my side, Irsquom pretty sure she has too. https:t.co uvYfQsxKRevoke Article  and remain in the EU. - Petitions https:t.co XTbPuLXdigAn issue as big and important as Brexit should not come down to petitions - that said,you are frustrated that the PM is just not listening, you can sign here. https:t.co XpZGrFBfhgldquoWe, the signatories of this letter, represent artists, producers, managers, businesses and s from across the Music Industry in the UK and are writing to express our real concerns over Brexit and the current direction of the UKrsquos proposed departure from the EU, the letter says.The Musicians Union, The Association of Independent Music, Music Managers Forum, the Music Producers Guild and British Academy of Songwriters, Composers  Authors join label executives from Ninja Tune, Domino Recording Company and Warp Records alongside management companies, agents, concert promoters and music festival organizers in signing the letter.

title: theresa-may-faces-public-and-parliamentary-backlash-as-brussels-thrashes-out-delay-options
story: An online petition calling for the UKrsquos withdrawal to be scrapped posted a record number of sign-ups, topping . million names by .pm.According to the Commons Petitions Committee nearly , signatures were being completed every minute over Thursday lunchtime, crashing the website because of the unprecedented number of visitors.Celebrities and MPs signed up. Actor Hugh Grant wrote: "Ive signed. And it looks like every sane person in the country is signing too. National emergency."SNP MP Angus Brendan MacNeil tweeted: ldquoNext week I will, with other MPs, apply for a debate under Standing Order  to push for Commons vote to #RevokeArticle.But No  said the Prime Minister had made clear failing to deliver on the Brexit result would be a failure of democracy and had ldquosaid many times she will not countenance revoking Article .Activity on the parliamentary website massively increased after Mrs Mayrsquos speech on Wednesday night, which caused a furious response from MPs after she blamed them for failing to implement the result of the  EU referendum and told frustrated voters: "I am on your side."The televised message was described as being ldquoterribly misjudged by Nicky Morgan, the former Education Secretary, who suggested it could reduce Commons support for the PMrsquos plan.It was even suggested Julian Smith, the Chief Whip, viewed the PMrsquos No  speech as ldquoappalling.But Downing St defended Mrs Mayrsquos comments, saying they had been intended as a "message to the public" to explain why she had decided to seek an extension to the Article  withdrawal process.There was also a suggestion ndash strongly rejected by No  ndash that the PMrsquos remarks could have endangered MPsrsquo safety.Nationalist MP Pete Wishart said in the Commons: ldquoIt was the height of irresponsibility for the Prime Minister to pitch the public against Parliament in the current climate on the back of real issues of intimidation and threats against Members in all parts of the House.It emerged Lindsay Hoyle, the Deputy Speaker, has written to all MPs ahead of potentially crunch Brexit votes next week, recommending them to take taxis home from Parliament and not to travel alone in the coming days because of security fears.Backbencher Anna Soubry, a leading Remainer, revealed she was unable to go home to her Nottinghamshire constituency this weekend because of the seriousness of death threats she was facing.John Bercow, the Speaker, also intervened, telling MPs: ldquoNone of you is a traitor and all of you are doing your besthellipThe sole duty of every Member of Parliament is to do what he or she thinks is right.The row emphasised the political pressure being heaped on Mrs Mayrsquos leadership.Tory backbencher Robert Halfon, one of  Tory MPs to see the PM in her Commons room, said it was ldquoa dferent prime minister we sawhellipShe looked exhausted by events. Askedshe was going to be swept aside by them, the Harrow MP replied: ldquoWe are going to find out next week.The CBI and TUC took the unusual step of joining forces to warn that Britain was facing a ldquonational emergency and to urge the PM to change course on Brexit.Carolyn Fairburn, Director General of the CBI, and Frances OrsquoGrady, the TUC General Secretary, said avoiding a no-deal was ldquoparamount and called for a Plan B to ldquoprotect workers, the economy and an open Irish border, commands a parliamentary majority, and is negotiable with the EU.In Brussels, talks overran signicantly as the implications of one delay option were weighed up against another by the EU leaders, who had to come up with a unanimous agreement.The session on Brexit was expected to last four hours but by early evening no conclusion had been reached and it continued over dinner, meaning that Mrs May, who was due to attend the meal, could not.Early indications were that the EU was prepared to grant a short Brexit extension to May  and not the June  date Mrs May had asked for, but still conditional on her getting her deal through the Commons next week.The PM addressed her fellow leaders for  minutes, the longest speech she had ever made at a European Council, but sources suggested she ldquodid not perform well. When asked what she would doshe lost the parliamentary vote, Mrs May failed to answer.According to one diplomatic source, a frustrated Emmanuel Macron, the French President, asked the PM: ldquoTheresa, where are we going After she left, EU leaders stayed to thrash out the options. They came to the conclusion that the PM would lose a vote next week and Britain faced crashing out of the EU without a deal on March .The May  proposal, flagged up in the draft communique, was rowed back on as leaders discussed the implications of a no-deal Brexit.One option raised by France and Belgium was allowing an unconditional extension until May  to allow Mrs May more time to try to push a deal through Parliament. This would have ensured the UK left before a May  summit in Romania to celebrate the "renewal" of Europe.Another option on the table was an unconditional extension to April , the final date by which the UK could opt to take part in the May - European Parliament elections, with the possibility of a further extensionit did.As the summit began Mr Macron, pointed out that only a short, technical extension was on offer andMPs rejected the agreement "it will guide everybody to a no-deal for sure". His remarks caused the pound to plunge by more than one per cent in its largest one-day fall this year, dropping to ..Describing the UK as being in "political crisis", the French President, said: "There needs to be a profound political changethere is to be an extension which is anything other than technical."Xavier Bettel, the Luxembourg Prime Minister, said: "At the moment, there are more non-options on the table than options...I sometimes have the feeling that we are in the waiting room, a bit like Waiting for Godot. But Godot never came so I hope this time they will come."In other developments ndash*The Ministry of Defence has set up an operations room in a bunker at its main Whitehall building to deal with a potential no-deal Brexit. The preparations are codenamed Operation Redfold.*Jeremy Corbyn held "very constructive discussions" in Brussels with Michel Barnier, the EU chief negotiator, and Martin Selmayr, the European Commission Secretary General, which had focused on the means to prevent a no-deal Brexit next Friday.*First Minister Nicola Sturgeon was confirmed as one of the keynote speakers at the Peoplersquos Rally in London on Saturday. Other speakers will include Lord Heseltine, the former Deputy Prime Minister, Sir Vince Cable, the Liberal Democrat leader, and Labourrsquos Jess Philips and the Greensrsquo Caroline Lucas.*DUP MP Sir Jeffrey Donaldson said his party and other MPs still needed "legal assurances" on the Irish backstop to support Mrs Mays deal but stressed he and colleagues would "work day and night" to get those assurances.

title: the-mod-cons-we-simply-cannot-live-without
story: From checking our bank balances on the move to learning how to fix the car using a YouTube tutorial, many would struggle to do without them.Modern day conveniences such as washing machines, microwaves and contactless payments, are among the most cherished items we simply cannot live without, according to a new survey.Researchers polled , UK adults to identy the everyday items which have most improved our lives.The analysis found sat navs, to find our way around unknown towns and cities, online banking services and the humble electric kettle and tumble drier are musts among lovers of modern conveniences.More recent additions,which make le just a little easier, include TV streaming services, social media and YouTube tutorials.Researchers found mod cons saved an average of  minutes a day or  days in total every year.The poll was commissioned for Heathrow Express to mark the introduction of contactless payments on its services.A spokesman said: ldquoWe are so used to having washing machines, fridges and so on thatrsquos it easy to forget what a dference they make to day-to-day le.Slow cookers, power showers and electric toothbrushes were also treasured by those quizzed in the poll.This was in addition to social media, which are considered a time waster as well as a time saver, video calling and air conditioning.Despite the huge strides in gadgetry in recent years % believe technology will make le even easier over the coming years.Flying cars, being able to teleport, along with robots which can heal you following an injury are among the conveniences we would most like to see become part of everyday le.The research carried out by OnePoll, found one-third of those questioned ldquowouldnrsquot be able to cope without dishwashers, tablets and contactless payments.However three-quarters of those asked believed the latest mod cons such as smartphones, smart fridges and smart TVs are overpriced.Six in  of those quizzed said they looked back fondly to a ldquopre-internet age when technology was not so advanced as ldquole was simpler then.But four in  said tech has helped them when theyrsquove found themselves in a tricky situation ndash for instance being able to pay for goods using their phone when theyrsquove forgotten their wallet.The research, carried out by OnePoll, also found the average Briton makes three contactless payments a day on average on their card or mobile device.Forty-three per cent regularly pay for their travel using contactless card payments ndash on average twice a week.Further to this,  per cent said going contactless and no longer needing to get around using traditional paper tickets would make their le easier.Other mod cons in the top  include high-speed wireless internet, cordless vacuum cleaners and toasters.The ubiquitous smart phone is among other items which the analysis found people could not live without.It was third in the poll, beaten only by fridge freezers and washing machines which secured the top spot in the list of items people could not live without.The humble electric kettle, which we all seem to forget when making a tea or coffee three or four times a day, was relegated to number  in the poll.High-speed wireless internet also joined tablet devices and laptops on the side of modern technology which also championed online shopping.The spokesman added: ldquoWe commissioned this research to find out which ones we rely on most and to seeany newer tech is now seen as essential by Brits.ldquoTraditional white goods took the top spots but newer tech such as smartphones, online banking and contactless payments featured prominently suggesting they are integral to our daily routine.

title: scotland-to-host-12-hour-dance-marathon
story: Now today in the north east of Scotland, seven dancers will make memories few who witness their performance will ever forget.A -hour ldquomarathon of dance and memory is being staged in Findhorn, Moray, between the hours of midday and midnight in the first ever performance of its kind.Wallflower is a production from Manchester-based performance company Quarantine, which sees dancers share their personal recollections of music, fashion, culture, politics and love, from their own le experiences through the form of dance, whether dancing alone in a nightclub, dancing at the Paris Opera Ballet or dancing with a dog across a beach.First staged in Wales four years ago, the production, which features a live DJ, has toured to Canada, the Netherlands, Sweden, Ireland and England in - minute and five-hour forms.Todayrsquos half-day debut in Scotland is the longest version of the show ever mounted, with amateur and professional performers dancing for  continuous hours.So far the production, which features a stark set comprising just a single chair and a disco ball, has seen almost , dances ldquoremembered by dancers, each one archived by the award-winning theatre company.The production was brought to the north of Scotland by Karl Jay-Lewin, creative director of Findhorn-based performance organisation Dance North, after he saw a previous event.He said: ldquoItrsquos basically a number of dancers literally remembering every dance theyrsquove ever danced. Itrsquos a live remembering of dancing, from all the experiences of anything that could constitute dance, whether they be dances on a stage or in the kitchen. Itrsquos quite an undertaking, itrsquos unique.ldquoSome dancers could be dancing for five hours so itrsquos a real challenge. And some of their dance stories are actually quite intimate and revealing.Ahead of the event, residents of the Moray village have been asked to create a picture of their own personal dance history, sharing memories to be displayed as part of an online archive of remembered dance and on display in the villagersquos Universal Hall where todayrsquos marathon is being held.Wallflower director Richard Gregory said: ldquoWallflower is way of using dance as a means of creating self portraits, a way of trying to remember who we are, and sharing that memory with other people. People find it emotionally moving without even being able to identy exactly why ndashtheyrsquore flooded with their own memories of dancing. Right from the very first time we did a five-hour version, wersquove found that something signicantly shted.

title: andrew-mckie-inept-theresa-may-could-lose-not-just-europe-but-the-uk
story: Politician, naturally, is high on the list of untrustworthy professions. Still,you want to offer reassurance that yoursquore well-intentioned and plain-dealing, it doesnrsquot seem sensible to branch out as a bogus psychic, one of the few lines of work that people distrust even more. Yet that was the Prime Ministerrsquos strategy on Wednesday evening, when she revealed herself in a public address as Mystic May, Mindreader.Like the late Doris Stokes communing with the aether and askingthe name Chris rings a bell with anyone in the audience, Mrs May revealed a series of revelations and occult certainties that had presumably been ulged to her by Higher Powers. MPs, she disclosed, are unworthy of your trust. ldquoAll [they] have been willing to say, she explained, ldquois what they do not want. She, by contrast, is ldquoabsolutely sure: You, the public, have had enough. Shersquos also had a ine revelation that what we donrsquot want is a second referendum, or a long delay in leaving.Some of us, blessed with extensive experience reading the newspapers, watching Sir John Curtice on the telly, and talking to people in pubs, have a dim sense that the matter is a little more complicated. Even the election of these MPs, after all, was an exercise in trying to find out what the public wants their inability to agree ndash in many cases, even with people in their own party ndash is a fair indication that the public does not possess a single view of Brexit that just happens to be identical to that of Mrs May, seer and Sybil. If you cast your mind back to the referendum, you may recall that there was a dference of opinion on whether we should leave or remain.Mrs Mayrsquos speech was, in at least one respect, illuminating. It presented in their shining glory all the characteristics that have made her one of the worst Prime Ministers ever. As well as the delusional psychic powers, it illustrated her intransigence, her authoritarian tendencies, her utter contempt for her Parliamentary colleagues, a naked populism that Pierre Poujade would have thought de trop, and total disdain for trivial obstacles such as objective reality or telling the truth.Read more: Alison Rowat: Mother of Parliaments is unfitIt may be true that therersquos precious little popular or parliamentary appetite, and no majority, for the Withdrawal Agreement, no deal, y delay, a second referendum or reversing the vote. But it is a flat lie to say MPs have been willing to say only what they donrsquot want. Theyrsquove been clamouring to say just that, and attempting to get indicative votes that might narrow the options down to what might actually get through the Commons. But theyrsquove been constantly frustrated by Mrs Mayrsquos refusal to acknowledge that anything other than her proposals should be considered.Mrs May said that she was elected to deliver what the people had decided on in the referendum. But she wasnrsquot actually elected , having thrown away the majority she inherited in what must be the most inept campaign ever staged. Only the fact that Jeremy Corbyn is even more useless than she is kept her in the job, with a majorityof precisely zero. But leave that aside.The more puzzling question is why she, a Remain voter, should think she possesses unique insight into what those who voted to leave the EU want. The options, which she refused to let anyone, evenher own Brexit secretaries, discuss or explore, were legion. Many of those who campaigned for Leave wanted, for instance, to remain in the single market ndash pointing to the Efta countries, such as Norway, or to Switzerland, with its comprehensive free trade and movement arrangements. The fact that some may now have hardened their position to argue that that is not ldquoreal Brexit is irrelevant itrsquos still leaving the EU.Instead of giving this any consideration, Mrs May set out a series of ldquored lines plucked from her own imagination, though we are now apparently expected to regard them as something along the lines of the golden tablets and rock spectacles delivered to the prophet Joseph Smith.Unsurprisingly, these did not correspond with the views of most Leave voters, who ndash despite attempts to characterise them as unormly bigoted and xenophobic ndash never once listed immigration as their first priority in any poll conducted before or after the referendum. They did, however, resemble Mrs Mayrsquos track record at the Home Office, when she was responsible for such measures as the ldquoHostile Environment and attempted to deport members of the Windrush generation who were perfectly entitled to live in the UK.Another of her priorities was the European arrest warrant and security co-operation, though she seems not to have considered the security implications for the Irish border, despite it having been the single greatest security issue for the UK for the past half-century.She has given no evidence that she understood the opportunities Brexit afforded for free trade, something which should have been given a high priority,only because of the possibility of a no-deal Brexit. Indeed, on trade issues the only impulse she has demonstrated is a willingness to cave in to rent-seekers amongst the large corporations and special interest groups.But then that is of a piece with Mrs Mayrsquos political philosophy, profoundly illiberal when it comes to regulation, immigration and human rights, and essentially left-wing on economic issues.She is a disastrous failure, not just as a Prime Minister, but as a Conservative leader. Her efforts to keep the party together have left it split more than at any time since the arguments over the repeal of the Corn Laws. Her professed Unionism has threatened both Ireland and Scotlandrsquos future in the UK.The tragedy is that,her deal goes through, it will be worse than all the other possible outcomes, andshe resigns because it fails to go through, the damage will already have been done. She may yet go down in history as an even worse PM than Lord North, who lost America. She could lose not just Europe, but the UK.
